PT J
AN ZOOR14901003037
DT Article
TI Discovery of carboniferous holothurian sclerites from the Benxi
   Formation, Pingshuo mining area, Shanxi province.
AU Gao, Lianfeng (ytgaolf@163.com) 
   Ding, Hui
   Zhang, Peng
   Wang, Yu
   Sun, Juan
SO Acta Micropalaeontologica Sinica
VL 29
IS 2
PS 179-194
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB More than 250 specimens of discrete holothurian sclerites have been
   extracted from acetic acid residues in the Danshuigou limestone(C2-1) of
   Benxi Formation from Pingshuo Mining Area, Shanxi Province and 27
   species in 13 genera (including 5 new species, 3 indeterminate species),
   1 genus and species indeterminate of holothurian sclerites are
   recognized. They are made up of the sclerites of different types, namely
   sieve plate, wheel, table, hooks, tetraradiate, ladle, and anchor. Five
   new species are represented by the sieve-type sclerites (Eocaudina
   encentrica sp. nov., E. cudgela sp. nov. and E. thicka sp. nov. )
   table-type sclerite (Priscopedatus lowspire.s sp. nov. ) and
   tetraradiate-type sclerite (Tetravirga asymmetrica sp. nov. ). Compared
   with those contemporaneous faunas in other parts of the world, most of
   the holothurian sclerites should be of the Moscovian in age. This
   discovery has greatly contributed to the holothurian sclerites
   biostratigraphic sequence in North China and researching of the
   coal-seam sedimentary environment.
C1 Gao, Lianfeng; College of Mining Engineering, Hebei United University,
   Tangshan, Hebei 063009, China, China.
EM ytgaolf@163.com
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1000-0674

   region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

PT J
AN ZOOR14901006543
DT Article
TI A revision of the genus Abderites Ameghino, 1887 (Marsupialia,
   Paucituberculata).
FT Revision del genero Abderites Ameghino, 1887 (Marsupialia,
   Paucituberculata).
AU Abello, Maria Alejandra (mabello@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
   Rubilar-Rogers, David
SO Ameghiniana
VL 49
IS 2
PS 164-184
PD Junio 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB In this, contribution, a taxonomic review for the genus Abderites
   Ameghino is presented. A comparative morphological analysis of the
   teeth, includ a review of the dental homology, was performed. The
   continuous quantitative characters were evaluated by means of a
   traditional morphometric analysis. As a result, three species were
   recognized for the Miocene of Argentina and Chile. From the eight
   species originally described: by Ameghino, only A. crispus Ameghino from
   the Colhuehuapian (early Miocene) of Argentina, and A. meridionalis
   Ameghino from the "Pinturan" and Santacrucian (late early Miocene) of
   Argentina, are considered valid species. In addition, this study allowed
   identification of new species, Abderites aisenense sp. nov., recorded in
   the Friasian s.s. and Colloncuran (middle Miocene) from Chile and
   Argentina repspectively. A. pristinus (Ameghino) previously recognized
   as valid species, is considered nomen dubium.
C1 Abello, Maria Alejandra; Laboratorio de Sistematica y Biologia Evolutiva
   (LASBE), Facultad de Ciencias Naturales y Museo (UNLP), Paseo del Bosque
   s/no, B1900FWA, La Plata, Argentina, Argentina.
EM mabello@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Paleontology

PT J
AN ZOOR14901006544
DT Article
TI Conodont biostratigraphy of the uppermost San Juan Formation and the
   lower member of Los Azules Formation at Cerro La Chilca, San Juan
   Precordillera.
FT Bioestratigrafia de conodontes del techo de la formacion San Juan y del
   miembro inferior de la Formacion Los Azules, Cerro La Chilca,
   Precordillera de San Juan.
AU Mestre, Ana (amestre@unsj.edu.ar) 
SO Ameghiniana
VL 49
IS 2
PS 185-197
PD Junio 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 4
AB The present contribution deals with a conodont association in the
   uppermost San Juan Formation and the lower member of the Los Azules
   Formation at the Cerro La Chilca union, Central Precordillera. The
   presence of key conodonts such as Eoplacognathus pseudoplanus (Viira),
   Histiodella kristinae Stouge and Microzarkodina sp. cf. M. ozarkodella
   Lindstrom suggests upper part of the E. pseudoplanus Zone. This is the
   first record of a conodonts association in the lower member of the Los
   Azules Formation. The biostratigraphic significance of "Bryantodina"
   aff. typicalis Stauffer is discussed. The middle Darriwilian E.
   pseudoplanus Zone is introduced for the Middle Ordovician
   biostratigraphic chart of the Precordillera. This zone is equivalent
   with at least the top of the Paroistodus horridus Subzone (Lenodus
   variabilis Zone), E. psuedoplanus/D. tablepointensis Zone, and kristinae
   Subzone (E. suecicus Zone).
C1 Mestre, Ana; Laboratorio de Micropaleontologia, Instituto de
   Investigaciones Mineras, Facultad de Ingenieria, Universidad Nacional de
   San Juan, Av. Libertador General San Martin 1109 (O), J5400ARL San Juan,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM amestre@unsj.edu.ar
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 0002-7014; 1851-8044
BD Ecology; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America; Geological time
   periods; Palaeozoic
DE Conodonta [Fossil assemblages /  / New record; systematics] [Argentina /
   San Juan, Cerro La Chilca / stratigraphical distribution] [Ordovician /
   Darriwilian / ]. 
TN Conodonts; Invertebrates

PT J
AN ZOOR14901006547
DT Article
TI A new species of rhea (Aves: Rheidae) from the Late Miocene of the
   Mesopotamia in Argentina.
FT Una nueva especie de nandu (Aves: Rheidae) del Mioceno Tardio de la
   Mesopotamia Argentina.
AU Agnolin, Federico L. (fedeagnolin@yahoo.com.ar) 
   Noriega, Jorge I.
SO Ameghiniana
VL 49
IS 2
PS 236-246
PD Junio 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new species of rhea, Pterocnemia mesopotamica sp. nov. (Ayes:
   Rheidae), from the late Miocene of Mesopotamia in Argentina is
   described. Specimens come from the base of the Ituzaingo Formation (=
   "Conglomerado osifero" or "Mesopotamiense"), which crops out along the
   cliffs of the Parana river near the homonimous city in Entre Rios
   Province. Pterocnemia mesopotamica sp. nov. is a slender and
   small-bodied bird, similar in size to the lesser rhea or choique (P
   pennata), and characterized by the marked divergence of the
   tarsometatarsal trochleae. Fragmentary remains of a femur and a humerus,
   identified as Rheidae indet., are also reported from the same locality
   and horizon. An isolated tarsometatarsus, coming from the Aisol
   Formation in Mendoza Province, is referred to Pterocnemia cf. P.
   mesopotamica sp. nov. If this record is confirmed, the biochron of the
   new taxon would extend back from the late Miocene (Huayquerian Age) to
   the middle Miocene (Friasian Age).
C1 Agnolin, Federico L.; Laboratorio de Anatomia Comparada y Evolucion de
   los Vertebrados, Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales "Bernardino
   Rivadavia", Av. Angel Gallarado, 470, 1405 Buenos Aires, Argentina,
   Argentina.
EM fedeagnolin@yahoo.com.ar

PT J
AN ZOOR14901002482
DT Article
TI ROOT-KNOT NEMATODES FROM ASPARAGUS AND ASSOCIATED BIOLOGICAL ANTAGONISTS
   IN PERU.
AU Murga-Gutierrez, S.N.
   Colagiero, M.
   Rosso, L.C.
   Sialer, M.M. Finetti
   Ciancio, A. (a.ciancio@ba.ipp.cnr.it) 
SO Nematropica
VL 42
IS 1
PS 57-62
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A research study on the parasitic nematodes of asparagus and several
   associated antagonists was carried out in Northern Peru. Nematodes were
   identified by means of light microscopy and sequencing of the ITS1-2
   regions. Nematophagous fungi were isolated from nematode-infested roots
   or soil, cultured in vitro and maintained in a culture collection for
   further characterization. The species recovered were mainly root-knot
   nematodes including Meloidogyne incognita and M. ethiopica.
   Nematophagous fungi identified through standard morphological methods as
   well as by ITS sequencing included Drechslerella brochopaga,
   Lecanicillium psalliotae and Monacrosporium sp. Meloidogyne ethiopica
   and the antagonistic fungi are new records for the country.
C1 Ciancio, A.; CNR, Ist Protez Piante, Via Amendola 122-D, Bari, I-70126,
   Italy, Italy.

DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF NEMATODES (CEPHALOBIDA: CHAMBERSIELLIDAE) FROM MOSS
   FROM NORTH AND SOUTH AMERICA.
AU del Prado, Cid (icid@colpos.mx) 
SO Nematropica
VL 42
IS 1
PS 108-114
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Two new species of the family Chambersiellidae Thorne, 1937 were
   collected in tropical forest (Ecuador) and temperate forest (Mexico)
   environments. Geraldius galapagoensis sp.n. is recognized by the head
   being separated from the body by a conspicuous constriction, the
   distance from the anterior end to the base of the oesophagus (141-207
   [mu]m), the short isthmus (32-49 [mu]m long), the vulva on a prominent
   vulval cone in the gravid females and the presence of a pair of vulval
   glands. The vulva is covered with a gelatinous-like material. The male
   is similar to the female, with a single testis extending anteriorly, not
   reflexed. Rectal glands present. Tail curved ventrally; tail terminuses
   dorsally hooked and slightly bifurcate. Pre-anal and post-anal papillae
   present. Two slightly curved spicules and conspicuous gubernaculum.
   Diastolaimus mexicanus sp.n. is characterized by the distance from the
   anterior end to the base of the oesophagus (189-236 [mu]m), isthmus
   length (60-92 [mu]m) and tail lengths of females and males (70-83 and
   61-82 [mu]m, respectively), and the presence of clearly bifurcate ends
   with hook-like mucros on tails of both females and males. The shape of
   the gubernaculum is also characteristic.
C1 del Prado, Cid; Colegio Postgrad, Montecillo, 56230, Mexico, Mexico.
EM icid@colpos.mx
SC Zoology
SN 0099-5444
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Oceanic islands; Pacific Ocean islands
DE Diastolaimus mexicanus [Mexico /  / New species]. 
   Geraldius galapagoensis [Galapagos Islands /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Diastolaimus mexicanus (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 110].

AN ZOOR14901002486
DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF NEMATODE, SCLERORHABDITIS NEOTROPICALIS SPN
   (RHABDITIDA), ASOCIATED WITH AZTECA ANTS IN CECROPIA OBTUSIFOLIA.
AU Esquivel, A. (aesquive@una.ac.cr) 
   Abolafia, J.
   Hanson, P.
   Pinto, A.
SO Nematropica
VL 42
IS 1
PS 163-169
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Sclerorhabditis neotropicalis sp. n. is described and illustrated. It
   can be distinguished by its body length (515-560 [mu]m in females and
   363-455 [mu]m in males), lip region with crown-shaped lips, having acute
   three acute thorns, oral aperture one third of lip region width, stoma
   15-22 [mu]m long or 1.0-1.6 times as long as diameter of lip region,
   stomatal tube about 1.5 times longer than wide, bearing rhabdia with
   slightly rugous walls at lumen side, stegostom lacking glottoid
   apparatus and denticles, pharynx 125-135 [mu]m long in females and
   107-131 [mu]m long in males, excretory pore and hemizonid located at
   21-22% of the distance from the anterior end. The female reproductive
   system is didelphic-amphidelphic, with ovaries straight or dorsally
   reflexed, and the vulva is a transverse slit, 55-61% from the anterior
   end, female tail conoid elongated, 62-76 [mu]m long, having a posterior
   hyaline portion very slender and with acute tip. The male reproductive
   system is monorchic, with testis anterio-ventrally reflexed, spicules
   free, 36-47 [mu]m long or 1.6-1.8 times longer than anal body width,
   with rounded manubrium, gubernaculum 15-18 [mu]m long or 38-42% of
   spicule length, and bursa anteriorly open, peloderan, with scalloped
   margin and bearing eight pairs of genital papillae (1+1/1+1+1+1+2), tail
   conoid spicate, 23-30 [mu]m long. The new species was found in close
   association with an ant colony (Azteca constructor Emery, 1876) inside a
   Cecropia obtusifolia Bertoloni, 1840 tree in a tropical rain forest in
   Costa Rica. Certain species of Azteca ants live in mutualistic
   association with Cecropia trees and preliminary evidence suggests that
   the new nematode species is invariably present in the colonies of at
   least some of these Azteca species. It is, therefore, possible that the
   new nematode species represents a third partner in the mutualism,
   although its role is still unknown.
C1 Esquivel, A.; Univ Nacl, Lab Nematol, Apartado 86-3000, Heredia, Costa
   Rica, Costa Rica.
EM aesquive@una.ac.cr
OI Abolafia Cobaleda, Joaquin/0000-0001-9640-236X
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0099-5444
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Associations; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; Central America
DE Azteca constructor [Associations / Sclerorhabditis neotropicalis
   (Nematoda) / New associate species] [Costa Rica /  / New associated
   nematode species]. 
   Sclerorhabditis neotropicalis [Associations / Azteca constructor
   (Hymenoptera) / New associate species] [Costa Rica /  / New species;
   hymenopteran associate]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Formicoidea, Formicidae, Nematoda

   Associated with Azteca constructor (Hymenoptera), p. 164].

TI Early Permian ostracods from Mugi County, Gifu Prefecture, central
   Japan.
AU Tanaka, Gengo (tanaka@gmnh.pref.gunma.jp) 
   Ono, Teruo
   Yuan, Aihua
   Ichida, Masahiro
   Maeda, Haruyoshi
SO Paleontological Research
VL 16
IS 2
PS 88-106
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The Early Permian organic-rich black coloured limestone from Mugi
   County, Gifu Prefecture, central Japan, was sampled for ostracods.
   Eleven species belonging to six genera were identified This ostracod
   assemblage is the first report of Palaeozoic species from central Japan.
   Nine species are new: Amphissites gifuensis Tanaka and Yuan sp. nov.,
   Aurikirkbya miyakei Tanaka and Ono sp. nov., Glyptopleura mugiensis
   Tanaka and Yuan sp. nov., Bairdia fujisan Tanaka and Maeda sp. nov.,
   Bairdia ikeyai Tanaka sp. nov., Bairdia spindlica Tanaka and Yuan sp.
   nov., Bairdia minoensis Tanaka and Ono sp. nov., Microcheilinella
   subovata Tanaka and Maeda sp. nov., and Microcheilinella tsubogawensis
   Tanaka and Ichida sp. nov.

PT J
AN ZOOR14901001770
DT Article
TI Miocene ostracodes from the Osaki Formation, Kukinaga Group,
   Tanegashima, Southwest Japan, and their significance for the
   biogeography of the Indo-West Pacific.
AU Yamaguchi, Tatsuhiko (tyamaguch@mac.com) 
   Mashiba, Hisakazu
   Kamiya, Takahiro
SO Paleontological Research
VL 16
IS 2
PS 107-123
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The Indo-West Pacific (IWP) benthos, which shows the highest diversity
   of marine organisms worldwide, is thought to have originated from the
   Tethys Ocean. Little is known about Miocene ostracodes in the IWP, that
   is, subsequent to the closure of the Tethys Ocean. To understand the
   paleobiogeography of Miocene ostracodes in the IWP, we examined
   ostracodes from the Middle Miocene-Lower Pliocene Osaki Formation,
   Kukinaga Group, at Tanegashima, Southwest Japan, revealing the presence
   of Neocytheromorpha, an IWP taxon that originated from South Australia.
   Neocytheromorpha occurs abundantly with Trachyleberis in Middle Miocene
   sublittoral deposits. This finding indicates that Neocytheromorpha
   migrated northward from South Australia, along the Australian coast, and
   settled in coastal areas of the West Pacific during the Oligocene-Middle
   Miocene. Because the migration coincided with diversification in the
   West Pacific and the invasion of corals and molluscs, it was synchronous
   with changes in the populations of the IWP biota. Two new species are
   systematically described: Acanthocythereis inouei sp. nov. and
   Neocytheromorpha priscipacifica sp. nov.
C1 Yamaguchi, Tatsuhiko; Scripps Institution of Oceanography, University of
   California San Diego, 206 Vaughan Hall, La Jolla Dr., MS-0244, La Jolla,
   CA 92093-0244, USA, USA.
EM tyamaguch@mac.com
OI Yamaguchi, Tatsuhiko/0000-0001-8967-2564
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1342-8144
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Neogene
DE Acanthocythereis inouei; Neocytheromorpha priscipacifica [Japan /  / new
   species] [Miocene /  / ]. 
   Neocytheromorpha [Zoogeography / Palaeobiogeography / New record] [Japan
   / Kyushu, Kagoshima, Tanegashima / ] [Miocene /  / ]. 
   Ostracoda [Japan / Ryukyu Islands, Tanegashima / faunal list;
   stratigraphical distribution; systematics] [Miocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda

   Miocene, P. 115; Fossil]. 
   Neocytheromorpha (Ostracoda): [Fossil; New record].

DT Article
TI Systematic and synonymic notes on Sinechostictus ictis (Antoine, 1931)
   (Insecta Coleoptera Carabidae Bembidiina).
FT Nota sistematica e sinonimica su Sinechostictus ictis (Antoine, 1931)
   (Insecta Coleoptera Carabidae Bembidiina).
AU Neri, Paolo (nerolit@alice.it) 
   Gudenzi, Ivo
   Pavesi, Maurizio
SO Quaderno di Studi e Notizie di Storia Naturale della Romagna
VL 35
PS 115-120
PD Guigno 2012
PY 2012
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB An almost mature male specimen of the type series of Sinechostictus
   ictis (Antoine, 1931), to be considered paralectotypus, allowed to study
   the hitherto unknown aedeagus morphology and to recognize a greater
   variability of external features than formerly believed. The supposed
   close relationship of S. ictis with S. barbarus (G. Muller, 1918) is
   excluded; S. ictis is put into synonymy of S. frederici (G. Muller,
   1918), of which it is merely an high altitude form with more rounded
   shoulders, of no systematic significance. Determination keys for
   Sinechostictus species of the "decoratus" group (Neri, Gudenzi&Pavesi,
   2009) are consequently updated.
C1 Neri, Paolo; via Guido Rossa, 21, San Lorenzo in Noceto, I-47121 Forli
   (FC), Italy, Italy.

DT Article
TI Description of new Riodinids from French Guiana (Lepidoptera,
   Riodinidae, Mesosemiini and Symmachiini).
FT Descriptions de nouveaux Riodinides de Guyane francaise (Lepidoptera,
   Riodinidae, Mesosemiini et Symmachiini).
AU Gallard, Jean-Yves (gallard.j-y@voila.fr) 
   Fernandez, Serge
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 117
IS 2
PS 187-192
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB Description of new Riodinids from French Guiana (Lepidoptera,
   Riodinidae, Mesosemiini and Symmachiini). In the Southern French Guiana,
   on Mount Itoupe (altitude 830 m), a Lepidoptera Riodinidae Mesosemia of
   a species only known from the Upper Amazon, was discovered and is
   described as a new subspecies with characteristic habitus: Mesosemia
   messeis itoupensis n. ssp. Moreover, in coastal forests of French
   Guiana, on the Kaw mountain, Pirascca arbuscula (Moschler, 1883) and two
   closely related species are collected : P. histrica (Stichel, 1910),
   regarded as a synonym by Callaghan&Lamas, 2004, is revalidated as bona
   species; Pirascca mimica n. sp. is described. These three species are
   illustrated, and information is provided on the behavior of imagos.
C1 Gallard, Jean-Yves; 19 Lotissement Victor, Cayenne, F-97300, France,
   France.
EM gallard.j-y@voila.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0037-928X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Mesosemia messeis itoupensis [French Guiana /  / New subspecies]. 
   Pirascca mimica [French Guiana /  / New species]. 
   Riodinidae [French Guiana /  / Systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Lycaenidae
OR Mesosemia messeis itoupensis (Lycaenidae): [Subsp nov, French Guiana, P.
   188]. 
   Pirascca arbuscula - (Moeschler 1883) (Lycaenidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, Pirascca histrica (Stichel 1910), p. 190]. 
   Pirascca arbuscula arbuscula - (Moeschler 1883) (Lycaenidae):
   [Redescription, P. 190]. 
   Pirascca histrica - (Stichel 1910) (Lycaenidae): [First time described,
   Male, p. 190; Removal from synonymy, With Pirascca arbuscula (Moeschler
   1883), p. 190]. 
   Pirascca mimica (Lycaenidae): [Sp nov, French Guiana, P. 191]. 
   Riodinidae (Lycaenidae).

U1 0

AB Descriptions of two new Athyreus MacLeay, 1819 (Coleoptera,
   Scarabaeoidea, Geotrupidae). Two new species of Athyreus are described:
   A. howdeni n. sp. from Uruguay and Paraguay, and A.thilliezi n. sp. from
   Brazil. Both species are illustrated.

TI New species in the genus Apotolamprus Olsoufieff, 1947, from Madagascar
   (Coleoptera, Scarabaeidae, Epilissini).
FT Nouvelles especes du genre Apotolamprus Olsoufieff, 1947, de Madagascar
   (Coleoptera, Scarabaeidae, Epilissini).
AU Montreuil, Olivier (o.montr@mnhn.fr) 
   Viljanen, Heidi

VL 117
IS 2
PS 243-246
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB New species in the genus Apotolamprus Olsoufieff, 1947, from Madagascar
   (Coleoptera, Scarabaeidae, Epilissini). Four species of the genus
   Apotolamprus Olsoufieff, 1947, are described and compared with their
   most related species: Apotolamprus sahatezaensis n. sp., A.
   pseudoquadrimaculatus n. sp., A. hagai n. sp. and A. andranobeensis n.
   sp.

DT Article
TI Eriophyoid Mites (Acari: Trombidiformes) from Orchid Island and Green
   Island, off the Southeast Coast of Taiwan, with the Description of a New
   Genus.
AU Wang, Chin-Fah
   Huang, Kun-Wei (eri@mail.nmns.edu.tw) 
SO Formosan Entomologist
VL 32
IS 2
PS 199-221
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This work describes 12 species of eriophyoid mites from Orchid Island
   (Lanyu) and Green Island (Ludao), including one new genus, seven new
   species and five new records (to Orchid Island). They are: Aceria
   noumeae (Keifer, 1978) (infesting Ficus heterapleura and Ficus ampelas),
   Proartacris melicopae sp. nov. (infesting Melicope triphylla),
   Proartacris pinnatus sp. nov. (infesting Pometia pinnata), Phaulacus
   lanyuensis sp. nov. (infesting Syzygium simile), Lanyuii exigus gen. et
   sp. nov. (infesting Tabernaemontana subglobosa), Latitudo sanasaii
   Huang, 2001 (infesting Symplocos cochinchinensis philippinensis),
   Tegonotus similis sp. nov. (infesting Syzygium simile), Tegonotus
   adamasimilis sp. nov. (infesting Chionanthus ramiflorus), Epitrimerus
   irisanus Huang and Wang, 2004 (infesting Ficus ampelas), Vasates
   irisanae Huang 1992 (infesting Ficus ampelas), Tegolophus melicopi Huang
   and Wang, 2004 (infesting Melicope triphylla) and Neopentamerus decem
   sp. nov. (infesting Melanolepis multiglandulosa). A key to the families,
   subfamilies, and species of eriophyoid mites from Orchid Island and
   Green Island is also provided.
C1 Huang, Kun-Wei; Natl Museum Nat Sci, Dept Zool, Taichung 40453, Taiwan,
   Taiwan.
EM eri@mail.nmns.edu.tw
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1680-7650
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Parasites diseases
   and disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   heterapleura / ] [Taiwan / Orchid Island / ].

   New record] [Taiwan / Orchid Island / ].

   Island & Orchid Island / Key to families; species; subfamilies & tribes]
   [ /  / faunal list].

   [Taiwan / Orchid Island / ].

DT Article
TI Two new species of Stenoloba (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae) from East Asia
   with the first description of S. nora female genitalia.
AU Sohn, Jae-Cheon (jsohn@umd.edu) 
   Tzuoo, Han-Rong
SO Journal of Asia-Pacific Entomology
VL 15
IS 2
PS 241-244
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Two new species of Stenoloba Staudinger, 1892 are described: S. ronkayi
   Sohn and Tzuoo sp. nov. from Taiwan and S. hystrix Sohn sp. nov. from
   northern Vietnam. The relationships of the new species with the actual
   species groups of Stenoloba are discussed. The formerly unknown female
   of S. nora Kononenko and Ronkay, 2001 and its genitalia are described
   here for the first time. [copyright] Korean Society of Applied
   Entomology, Taiwan Entomological Society and Malaysian Plant Protection
   Society, 2011. Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 Sohn, Jae-Cheon; Univ Maryland, Dept Entomol, 4112 Plant Sci Bldg,
   College Pk, MD 20742, USA, USA.
EM jsohn@umd.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1226-8615

   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Stenoloba hystrix [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
   Stenoloba nora [Taiwan / Mt Hohuanshan / Systematics]. 
   Stenoloba ronkayi [Taiwan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Noctuoidea, Noctuidae
OR Stenoloba hystrix - Sohn 2012 (Noctuidae): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 242]. 
   Stenoloba nora - Kononenko & Ronkay 2001 (Noctuidae): [First time
   described, Female, p. 243].

PT J
AN ZOOR14812076285
DT Article
TI Resurrection of the genus Yezoterpnosia Matsumura (Hemiptera: Cicadidae:
   Cicadini) based on a new definition of the genus Terpnosia Distant.
AU Lee, Young June (cicaderolee@gmail.com) 
SO Journal of Asia-Pacific Entomology
VL 15
IS 2
PS 255-258
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The genus Terpnosia Distant is newly defined. Terpnosia elegans (Kirby)
   stat. rev, is resurrected from junior synonymy with Terpnosia psecas
   (Walker). Seven species are now considered to belong to Terpnosia sensu
   stricto, including two species currently placed in this genus: T. psecas
   (Walker) and T. elegans (Kirby) stat. rev. Five species are transferred
   from Pomponia Stal to Terpnosia: T. polei (Henry) comb. nov., T. lactea
   (Distant) comb. nov., T. similis (Schmidt) comb. nov., T. simusa
   (Boulard) comb. nov., and T. graecina (Distant) comb. nov. Yezoterpnosia
   Matsumura stat. rev, is resurrected from junior synonymy with Terpnosia.
   Six species formerly in the genus Terpnosia are transferred to
   Yezoterpnosia: Y. nigricosta (De Motschulsky), Y. ichangensis (Liu)
   comb. nov., Y. shaanxiensis (Sanborn) comb. nov., Y. vacua (Olivier)
   comb. nov., Y. obscura (Kato) comb. nov., and Y. fuscoapicalis (Kato)
   comb. nov. Terpnosia is placed in the subtribe Psithyristriina of the
   tribe Cicadini, and Yezoterpnosia is placed in the subtribe
   Leptopsaltriina of Cicadini. Terpnosiina syn. nov. is synonymized with
   Psithyristriina. [copyright]Korean Society of Applied Entomology, Taiwan
   Entomological Society and Malaysian Plant Protection Society, 2012.
   Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 Lee, Young June; Univ Connecticut, Dept Ecol & Evolutionary Biol, 75 N
   Eagleville Rd, Storrs, CT 06269, USA, USA.
EM cicaderolee@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1226-8615
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Terpnosiaria; Yezoterpnosia [Asia /  / Systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Cicadoidea, Cicadidae
OR Leptopsaltriina (Cicadidae): [Removal from synonymy, Terpnosiaria Kato
   1932, p. 257]. 
   Pomponia graecina - Distant 1889 (Cicadidae): [Referred to, Terpnosia,

   Yezoterpnosia, p. 257].

   from Pomponia, p. 257]. 
   Terpnosia ichangensis - Liu 1940 (Cicadidae): [Referred to,
   Yezoterpnosia, p. 257].

   from Pomponia, p. 257]. 
   Terpnosia obscura - Kato 1938 (Cicadidae): [Referred to, Yezoterpnosia,
   p. 257]. 
   Terpnosia polei - (Henry 1931) (Cicadidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Pomponia, p. 257]. 
   Terpnosia psecas - (Walker 1850) (Cicadidae): [Comb nov, Transferred

   from Terpnosia, p. 257].

PT J
AN ZOOR14812076287
DT Article
TI Lophomyrmex terraceensis, a new ant species (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in
   the bedoti group with a revised key.
AU Bharti, Himender (himenderbharti@gmail.com) 
   Kumar, Rakesh
SO Journal of Asia-Pacific Entomology
VL 15
IS 2
PS 265-267
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Lophomyrmex terraceensis sp. nov. is described from India. This species
   belongs to the bedoti group of the genus Lophomyrmex, which is
   characterized by a pronotum with lateral irregular marginations. The new
   species can be separated from other species within this group by the
   presence of sub-parallel, blunt and thick propodeal spines of almost
   uniform diameter and by an obliquely truncate petiolar node.
   [copyright]Korean Society of Applied Entomology, Taiwan Entomological
   Society and Malaysian Plant Protection Society, 2012. Published by
   Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 Bharti, Himender; Punjabi Univ, Dept Zool & Environm Sci, Patiala,
   Punjab 147002, India, India.
EM himenderbharti@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1226-8615
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Lophomyrmex terraceensis [Himachal Pradesh /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Formicoidea, Formicidae
OR Lophomyrmex bedoti group (Formicidae): [Key to species, P. 267]. 
   Lophomyrmex terraceensis (Formicidae): [Sp nov, Himachal Pradesh, P.
   266].

DT Article
TI A new genus and species in the cicada tribe Cicadini (Hemiptera:
   Cicadidae) from Thailand.
AU Lee, Young June (cicaderolee@gmail.com) 
SO Journal of Asia-Pacific Entomology
VL 15
IS 2
PS 287-289
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new cicada genus and species, Kaphsa concordia gen. et sp. nov., is
   described from Chaiyaphum, Thailand. Haphsa aculeus Lee is transferred
   to Kaphsa to become Kaphsa aculeus (Lee) comb. nov. The new genus Kaphsa
   is closely related to Haphsa Distant and is placed in the subtribe
   Dundubiina of the tribe Cicadini. [copyright] Korean Society of Applied
   Entomology, Taiwan Entomological Society and Malaysian Plant Protection
   Society, 2012. Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

AB Descriptions of two new species Aenictus indicus sp. nov. and Aenictus
   wilsoni sp. nov. are provided from India. The presence of an unusual
   distinct ridge between mesonotum and mesopleuron relates them to three
   sympatric Philippine species, Aenictus philippinensis Chapman, 1963:
   Aenictus rabori Chapman, 1963 and Aenictus pangantihoni Zettel and
   Sorger, 2010. An identification key to the worker caste of Indian

TI Lecithoceridae (Gelechioidea, Lepidoptera) of New Guinea, Part X: Review
   of the genus Lecithocera with descriptions of ten new species.
AU Park, Kyu-Tek (ktpark02@gmail.com) 
SO Journal of Asia-Pacific Entomology
VL 15
IS 2
PS 313-327
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Twenty-six species of the genus Lecithocera Herrich-Schaffer known from
   New Guinea (Papua New Guinea and Papua, Indonesia) are reviewed,
   including descriptions of ten new species (L. biaroensis sp. nov., L.
   brunneibella sp. nov., L inkyuleei sp. nov., L hispidiella sp. nov., L.
   gyrosiella sp. nov., L spinulata sp. nov., L stichoides sp. nov., L.
   ceratoides sp. nov., L. porrectiella sp. nov., and L. lasioides sp.
   nov.). Lecithocera strepsicrena Meyrick and L. spinigera Diakonoff are
   synonymized with L. straurophora Meyrick. Adults and genitalia of all
   known species are illustrated, except six species whose types are
   unknown. In addition, a preliminary check list of the genus Lecithocera
   for New Guinea is provided. [copyright]Korean Society of Applied
   Entomology, Taiwan Entomological Society and Malaysian Plant Protection
   Society, 2012. Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

DT Article
TI Two new scaritine beetles of the genera Leleuporella Basilewsky, 1956,
   and Striganoviella, gen.n., from Vietnam (Coleoptera: Carabidae).
AU Fedorenko, D.N. (dmitri-fedorenko@yandex.ru) 
SO Russian Entomological Journal
VL 21
IS 2
PS 127-132
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new scaritine carabids, Leleuporella tuberculata sp.n. and
   Striganoviella subopaca gen.n.&sp.n., are described from Vietnam. The
   former genus belongs to the subtribe Clivinina, Clivinini, and is first
   recorded in Indochina, this being a far eastward extension of the genus
   range within the Oriental realm. The latter genus is a member of the
   tribe Dyschiriini and established here for the species which shows a
   particular combination of characters. Some of them are unique for the
   tribe while some others, e.g., secondarily entire postmentum, occur
   nowhere else but in the North American genus Akephorus LeConte, 1851.
C1 Fedorenko, D.N.; AN Severtsov Inst Ecol & Evolut, Leninsky Pr 33,
   Moscow, 119071, Russia, Russia.
EM dmitri-fedorenko@yandex.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0132-8069

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   Leleuporella tuberculata; Striganoviella subopaca [Vietnam /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Carabidae

TI An unusual new species of the millipede genus Glyphiulus Gervais, 1847
   from Borneo (Diplopoda: Spirostreptida: Cambalopsidae).
AU Golovatch, S.I.
   Geoffroy, J.-J.
   Mauries, J.-P.
   VandenSpiegel, D.
SO Russian Entomological Journal
VL 21
IS 2
PS 133-137
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The large, basically Southeast Asian genus Glyphiulus appears to be
   represented in the fauna of Borneo (Kalimantan, Indonesia) by a new,
   quite aberrant species, G. striganovae sp.n., which fails to readily fit
   into either of the two species groups currently delimited in the genus,
   i.e. the granulatus- or the javanicus-group. This new species
   tentatively remains ungrouped pending the discovery of further congeners
   south of Malay Peninsula, including Borneo.

TI A new Trichoncoides Denis, 1950 (Aranei: Linyphiidae) from a semi-desert
   in the Caspian Lowland.
AU Tanasevitch, Andrei V. (and-tan@mail.ru) 
   Piterkina, Tatyana V.
SO Russian Entomological Journal
VL 21
IS 2
PS 189-196
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new linyphiid species of the genus Trichoncoides is described from a
   clayey semi-desert in the environs of both Dzhanybek, western Kazakhstan
   and Lake Elton, Volgograd Area, southern Russia. The new species is
   similar to T. piscator (Simon, 1884), but differs well by the peculiar
   shape of the palpal tibia, of the anterior radical process in the male,
   as well as by the details of epigyne and vulva structure in the female.

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Indomyrma Brown, 1986 (Hymenoptera:
   Forrnicidae: Myrmicinae) from Vietnam.
AU Zryanin, V.A. (zryanin@list.ru) 
SO Russian Entomological Journal
VL 21
IS 2
PS 223-228
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB One new ant species of the subfamily Myrmicinae, Indomyrma bellae sp.n.
   is described from Cat Tien National Park (Southern Vietnam) based on
   workers and dealate queen. The genus Indomyrma was hitherto known only
   from one species, I. dasypyx Brown, 1986, described from two localities
   of the Southwestern India. A new species differs from I. dasypyx in the
   worker and queen by smaller body size, reduction of erect hairs on
   alitrunk, petiole and postpetiole, shape of anterodorsal margin of
   pronotum and petiolar node, features of the sculpture and strongly
   reduction (only 2-3 ommatidia) of eye in workers. The sting apparatus of
   genus Indomyrma is described for the first time. Biogeography analysis
   of the genus Indomyrma is given.
C1 Zryanin, V.A.; Lobachevsky State Univ Nizhni Novgorod, Dept Zool,
   Gagarin Prospect 23,Build 1, Nizhniy Novgorod, 603950, Russia, Russia.
EM zryanin@list.ru
RI Zryanin, Vladimir/D-5901-2015
SC Zoology
SN 0132-8069
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia

   Formicoidea, Formicidae

DT Article
TI Tardigrades of North America: Archechiniscus biscaynei, nov. sp.
   (Arthrotardigrada: Archechiniscidae), a Marine Tardigrade from Biscayne
   National Park, Florida.
AU Miller, William R. (William.Miller@BakerU.edu) 
   Clark, Tiffany
   Miller, Cullen
SO Southeastern Naturalist
VL 11
IS 2
PS 279-286
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 2
U2 11
AB During the 2010 National Park Service BioBlitz at Biscayne National
   Park, Homestead, FL, barnacles were collected from a submerged mangrove
   log near the Park headquarters. From the washings of the crushed
   barnacles, Archechiniscus biscaynei nov. sp. was extracted. This new
   species can be distinguished by its lack of a median cirrus, its large
   peduncles at the base of the external claws, the rounded cephalic clava
   between the internal and external cephalic cirri, a club-shaped papilla
   above the base of leg IV, and bulbous papilla just above the claws on
   the anterior of legs I, II, and III. A table of comparison of
   characteristics among the four known species and a key to their
   identification are provided.
C1 Miller, William R.; Baker Univ, Dept Biol, Baldwin City, KS 66006, USA,
   USA.
EM William.Miller@BakerU.edu
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1528-7092
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key;
   Associations; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Archechiniscus biscaynei [Associations / Cirripedia (Crustacea) / New
   associate species] [Gulf of Mexico / USA, Florida / New species;
   crustacean associate]. 
   Cirripedia [Associations / Archechiniscus biscaynei (Tardigrada) / New
   associate species] [Gulf of Mexico / USA, Florida / New associated
   tardigrade species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Tardigrada
OR Cirripedia (Crustacea). 
   Archechiniscus - Schulz 1953 (Tardigrada): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 284; Key to species, P. 284]. 
   Archechiniscus biscaynei (Tardigrada): [Sp nov, USA, Florida (marine),
   Associated with Cirripedia (Crustacea), p. 281].

DT Article
TI New, rare and poorly investigated species of the genera Opisthocystis
   and Gyratrix (Plathelminthes, Turbellaria, Kalyptorhynchia) from Lake
   Baikal.
AU Zaytseva, E.P. (tim@lin.irk.ru) 
   Timoshkin, O.A.
   Gutsol, M.V.
   Lukhnev, A.G.
SO Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 91
IS 6
PS 648-656
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 4
AB The illustrated descriptions of three new microturbellarian species of
   the genus Opisthocystis Sekera 1911 (Opisthocystis gyratricelloides
   Timoshkin et Zaytseva sp. n.; O. kremlevae Timoshkin, Zaytseva et Gutsol
   sp. n., and O. boykoi Timoshkin, Gutsol et Zaytseva sp. n.) inhabiting
   the sandy shallow littoral zone of Lake Baikal are presented. All these
   species were collected from depths less than 3 m in the sandy ground;
   they should be considered as representatives of the Baikal psammophylous
   communities. All the worms have the conservative structure of most organ
   systems, typical for representatives of the Opisthocystis genus. Special
   attention is paid to the structure of the male copulative apparatus (in
   particular, to the distal end of the prostatic stylet). The first data
   on the structure and external appearance of teratic and non-typical
   Gyratrix and Opisthocystis specimens from Lake Baikal are also given.
C1 Zaytseva, E.P.; Russian Acad Sci, Siberian Branch, Irkutsk, 664033,
   Russia, Russia.
EM tim@lin.irk.ru
RI Timoshkin, Oleg/J-4483-2018

PT J
AN ZOOR14811074017
PM 22815372
DT Article
TI Hard and Soft Anatomy in Two Genera of Dondersiidae (Mollusca,
   Aplacophora, Solenogastres).
AU Scheltema, Amelie H. (ascheltema@whoi.edu) 
   Schander, Christoffer
   Kocot, Kevin M.
SO Biological Bulletin (Woods Hole)
VL 222
IS 3
PS 233-269
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Phylogenetic relationships and identifications in the aplacophoran taxon
   Solenogastres (Neomeniomorpha) are in flux largely because descriptions
   of hard parts-sclerites, radulae, copulatory spicules-and body shape
   have often not been adequately illustrated or utilized. With easily
   recognizable and accessible hard parts, descriptions of Solenogastres
   are of greater use, not just to solenogaster taxonomists, but also to
   ecologists, paleontologists, and evolutionary biologists. Phylogenetic
   studies of Aplacophora, Mollusca, and the Lophotrochozoa as a whole,
   whether morphological or molecular, would be enhanced. As an example,
   morphologic characters, both isolated hard parts and internal anatomy,
   are provided for two genera in the Dondersiidae. Five species are
   described or redescribed and earlier descriptions corrected and
   enhanced. Three belong to Dondersia: D. festiva Hubrecht, D. incali
   (Scheltema), and D. namibiensis n. sp., the latter differentiated
   unambiguously from D. incali only by sclerites and copulatory spicules.
   Two species belong to Lyratoherpia: L. carinata Salvini-Plawen and L.
   californica (Heath). Notes are given for other species in Dondersiidae:
   L. bracteata Salvini-Plawen, Ichthyomenia ichthyodes (Pruvot), and
   Heathia porosa (Heath). D. indica Stork is synonymized with D. annulata.
   A cladistic morphological analysis was conducted to examine the utility
   of hard parts for reconstructing solenogaster phylogeny. Results
   indicate mono-phyly of Dondersia and Lyratoherpia as described here.
C1 Scheltema, Amelie H.; Woods Hole Oceanog Inst, Dept Biol, Woods Hole,
   MA, 02543, USA, USA.
EM ascheltema@whoi.edu
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0006-3185
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Diagnosis;
   Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   General morphology; Evolution; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Dondersia; Dondersiidae; Lyratoherpia [General morphology / Hard & soft
   anatomy / systematics] [Phylogeny / Cladistics / ]. 
   Dondersia namibiensis [South Atlantic / South Africa / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Aplacophora
OR Dondersia - Hubrecht 1888 (Aplacophora). 
   Dondersia annulata - Nierstrasz 1902 (Aplacophora): [Syn nov, Dondersia
   indica Stork 1941, p. 239]. 
   Dondersia californica - Heath 1911 (Aplacophora): [Referred to,
   Lyratoherpia, p. 244]. 
   Dondersia festiva - Hubrecht 1888 (Aplacophora): [Redescription, P.

   Dondersia incali - (Scheltema 1999) (Aplacophora): [Redescription, P.
   237]. 
   Dondersia namibiensis (Aplacophora): [Sp nov, South Africa (marine), P.
   238]. 
   Dondersiidae - Simroth 1893 (Aplacophora). 
   Lyratoherpia - Salvini-Plawen 1978 (Aplacophora): [Emended diagnosis, P.

   P. 243; Comb nov, Transferred from Dondersia, p. 244]. 
   Lyratoherpia carinata - Salvini-Plawen 1978 (Aplacophora): [Lectotype

   Lyratoherpia? bracteata (Aplacophora): [Taxonomic position, P. 244].

PT J

DT Article
TI [Revision of the genus Polyzonus Dejean, 1835 and related genera
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Callichromatini).]
FT Revision del genero Polyzonus Dejean, 1835 y generos afines (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Callichromatini).
AU Bentanachs, Joan (jbentanachs@hotmail.com) 
SO Cahiers Magellanes
VL 8
PS 1-100
PD Juillet 2012
PY 2012
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Polyzonus Dejean, 1835 is revised, which can be divided into
   four subgenera: Polyzonus (Parapolyzonus) (n. subg.), Polyzonus
   (Polyzonides) Podany, 1980, Polyzonus (Polyzonus) Dejean, 1835 and
   Polyzonus (Striatopolyzonus) n. subg. The former Polyzonus
   (Parapolyzonus) (n. subg.) is comprising Polyzonus bentanachsi Vives,
   2009, Stenochroma copei Vives et al., 2009 (n. comb.), Polyzonus
   drumonti Bentanachs, 2010, Promeces prasinus White, 1853, Polyzonus
   schmidti Schwarzer, 1926 and Polyzonus trocolii (n. sp.); Polyzonus
   (Polyzonides) Podany, 1980 include Polyzonus dohertyi Jordan, 1894 and
   Polyzonus obtusus Bates, 1879; Polyzonus (Polyzonus) Dejean, 1835 that
   comprises Polyzonus auroviridis Gressitt, 1942, Polyzonus balachowskii
   Gressitt-Rondon, 1970, Polyzonus bizonatus White, 1853, Polyzonus
   brevipes Gahan, 1906, Polyzonus cuprarius Fairmaire, 1887, Saperda
   fasciata Fabricius, 1781, Polyzonus flavocinctus Gahan, 1906, Polyzonus
   fucosahenus Gressitt-Rondon, 1970, Polyzonus laurae Fairmaire, 1887,
   Polyzonus pakxensis Gressitt-Rondon, 1970, Polyzonus saigonensis Bates,
   1879, Promeces sinensis Hope, 1841, Polyzonus subtruncatus Bates, 1879,
   Polyzonus violaceus Plavilstshikov, 1933, and Chelidonium yunnanum
   Podany, 1974 (n. comb.). The latter Polyzonus (Striatopolyzonus) (n.
   subg.), include Polyzonus hefferni Vives et al., 2008, Chelidonium
   luteonotatus Pic, 1928, Polyzonus nitidicollis Pic, 1932 and Cerambyx
   tetraspilotus Hope 1935. Due to a lack of the types, the position of two
   species remains still uncertain: Polyzonus democraticus Lameere, 1890
   and Polyzonus similis Podany, 1980. Based on both external main features
   and male genitalia, two new genera are suggested: Pseudopolyzonus (n.
   gen.), comprising Polyzonus latefasciatus Hudepohl, 1998 (n. comb), and
   Laosaphrodisium (n. gen.), comprising Laosaphrodisium amadori (n. sp.),
   Cataphrodisium cyaneum Gressitt-Rondon, 1970 (n. comb), Aphrodisium
   crassum Gressitt, 1939 (n. comb), Polyzonus optimum Bates, 1879 (n.
   comb), Polyzonus superbum Pic, 1923 (n. comb), Chelidonium gibbicolle
   var. subplicatum Pic, 1937 (n, comb) and Polyzonus watsoni Gahan, 1906
   (n. comb). Also one species is transferred: Polyzonus parvulus
   Gressitt-Rondon, 1970 to Chloridolum (Leontium) Thomson, 1864 (n. comb).
   Finally some synonymies are suggested as follow: Polyzonus opacus Pic,
   1946 (n. syn) with Polyzonus obtusus Bates, 1879, Polyzonus fupingensis
   Xie-Wang, 2009 (n. syn) with Saperda fasciata Fabricius, 1781, Polyzonus
   laosensis Pic, 1923 (n. syn) with Polyzonus saigonensis Bates, 1879,
   Polyzonus latemacuiatus Gressitt-Rondon, 1970 (n. syn) with Cerambyx
   tetraspilotus Hope, 1835, Polyzonus siamensis Podany, 1980 (n. syn) with
   Cataphrodisium cyaneum Gressitt-Rondon, 1970, Cataphrodisium callichroos
   Gressitt-Rondon, 1970 (n. syn) with Polyzonus watsoni Gahan, 1906, the
   genus Quettania Schwarzer, 1931 (n. syn) with Osphranteria Redtenbacher
   1850 and Polyzonus (Polyzonides) mirabilis Podany 1980 (n. syn) and
   Quettania coeruleipennis Schwarzer, 1931 (n. syn) with Osphranteria
   coerulescens Redtenbacher, 1850.

   Picasso s/n, 08003 Barcelona, Spain, Spain.

DT Article
TI [Contribution on the knowledge of longhorn beetles of Peru II. Two new
   longhorn beetles (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).]
FT Contribution a la connaissance des longicornes du Perou II. Deux
   nouveaux lamiaires (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
AU Touroult, Julein (touroult@wanadoo.fr) 
   Demez, Patrick
SO Cahiers Magellanes
VL 8
PS 101-105
PD Juillet 2012
PY 2012
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new remarkable lamiine longhorn beetles are described from Peru.
   Taurolema nigroolivacea n. sp. represent the 16th species from this
   genus in the small tribe Mauesiini Lane, 1956. It is a concolourus
   species, dark green and relatively elongated. Tuberolamia grilloides n.
   sp. is the second known species from this apterous genus from highland
   belonging to the tribe Morimopsini Mulsant, 1839. Its habitus reminds
   that of a cricket.
C1 Touroult, Julein; 15 avenue Christophe Colomb, F-16800 Soyaux, France,
   France.

TI A new species Glenea weigeli n. sp. from Yunnan, China, compared with

   Saperdini).
AU Lin, Meiying (linmeiying@ioz.ac.cn) 
   Liu, Feng
SO Cahiers Magellanes
VL 8
PS 113-117
PD Juillet 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species Glenea weigeli n. sp. is described from Yunnan, China. It
   can be distinguished from G. loosdregti Breuning, 1965 by antennal scape
   without a ridge, elytral apex without long spine at outer angle and
   different pubescent markings on elytra. A supplementary description of
   the most similar species G. loosdregti is made. G. fuscovitticollis
   Breuning, 1965 is synonymized with G. loosdregti Breuning, 1965 based on
   type material.

   (Heteroptera: Aphelocheiridae).

SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 122
IS 3
PS 111-113
PD Juni 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of benthic water bugs, Aphelocheirus (s. str.) goellnerae
   sp. nov., is described from Madagascar. It is unique among its congeners
   by possessing numerous peg-like, standing setae on a large portion of
   the dorsal surface, by a characteristically shaped left paramere, and by
   the female's subgenital plate with special modifications.

DT Article
TI Petasolentia goellnerae gen. nov., sp. nov. a new genus and species of
   Chryxinae (Heteroptera: Reduviidae).
AU Weirauch, Christiane (christiane.weirauch@ucr.edu) 
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 122
IS 3
PS 119-122
PD Juni 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and species of the small Neotropical assassin bug group
   Chryxinae, Petasolentia goellnerae gen. nov., sp. nov., is described
   from lowland rainforest in Southeastern Peru, increasing the small
   subfamily to comprise four genera and five species. The new genus stands
   out among genera of Chryxinae by the unique process on the frons and the
   angular postocular region. Additional diagnostic features are the small
   size, lack of ocelli, large eyes, the ventrolateral process on the gena,
   and the distinct venation on the corium. Images illustrating morphology
   and coloration of the new tax-on are provided.
C1 Weirauch, Christiane; Department of Entomology, University of
   California, Riverside, USA, USA.
EM christiane.weirauch@ucr.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8843
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America

DT Article
TI A new genus and new species of the tribe Dinocampini from Napo Province
   in Ecuador (Hymenoptera: Braconidae: Euphorinae).
AU Shaw, Scott R. (braconid@uwyo.edu) 
SO International Journal of Tropical Insect Science
VL 32
IS 2
PS 101-107
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new genus and a new species of the parasitoid wasp, Napo townsendi
   (Hymenoptera: Braconidae: Euphorinae: Dinocampini), is described from
   the Yanayacu Biological Station in Napo Province, Ecuador. The new genus
   and species is diagnosed and compared with the most closely related
   genus Betelgeuse Shaw and other Dinocampini. While first discovered by
   yellow bowl and Malaise trapping, it has more recently been discovered
   that males of N. townsendi can be found preferentially perching on the
   leaves of seedlings of the asteraceous tree Dendrophorbium lloense
   (Hieron) C. Jeffrey.

   Misumi, Hitoko
SO Medical Entomology and Zoology
VL 63
IS 2
PS 109-112

LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Neotrombicula teuriensis n. sp. is described and illustrated. The type
   material was collected from the nesting grounds of the Rhinoceros Auklet
   Cerorhinca monocerata (Pallas, 1811) on Teuri Island, Hokkaido, Japan.
   This new species may be distinguished easily by a 2-pronged palpotibial

   arrangement of 2-8-6-6-4-4-2.

PT J

DT Article
TI A new species of Microraptor from the Jehol Biota of northeastern China.
AU Gong, En-Pu
   Martin, Larry D.
   Burnham, David A. (ldmartin@ku.edu) 
   Falk, Amanda R.
   Hou, Lian-Hai
SO Palaeoworld
VL 21
IS 2
PS 81-91
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 25
AB Herein we describe a new species of Microraptor from northeastern China
   that provides new information on the characteristics of the genus and
   anatomical details suggesting a gliding behaviour. Although specimens of
   Microraptor have been known for at least a decade, the completeness of
   the new fossil provides additional morphology that highlights the
   uniqueness of this taxon. The new specimen, Microraptor hanqingi, is the
   key to understanding the evolutionary significance of hindlimb wings. A
   four-winged structure present on an organism sharing an evolutionary
   lineage leading to modern birds implies that gliding was a stage in the
   development of avian flight. M. hanqingi represents the largest known
   microraptorian from China with a total length of approximately 1 m, and
   was closely-related to the venomous form, Sinornithosaurus. CPR 2012
   Elsevier B.V. and Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, CAS.
   All rights reserved.
C1 Burnham, David A.; Univ Kansas, Nat Hist Museum, 1345 Jayhawk Blvd,
   Lawrence, KS 66045, USA, USA.
EM ldmartin@ku.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1871-174X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Microraptor hanqingi [Liaoning /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Saurischia,
   Theropoda
OR Microraptor - Xu et al 2000 (Theropoda): [Emended diagnosis, P. 82;
   Fossil]. 
   Microraptor hanqingi (Theropoda): [Sp nov, Liaoning, Cretaceous, P. 82;
   Fossil]. 
   Microraptorinae - Senter et al 2004 (Theropoda): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   82; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14811074476
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Revision of two species of ?Ulocrinus and a new pelecocrinid crinoid
   from West Timor.
AU Webster, G.D. (webster@wsu.edu) 
   Donovan, Stephen K.
SO Palaeoworld
VL 21
IS 2
PS 108-115
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two cladid crinoid species, ?Ulocrinus indicus Wanner, 1924, and
   ?Ulocrinus conoideus Wanner, 1937, are reinterpreted as cladid crinoids
   that do not belong to the cromyocrinids. This justifies Warmer's
   questioning of the generic assignment. ?Ulocrinus indicus has bifascial
   radial facets and is considered an advanced intermediate dendrocrinid
   assigned to the incertae superfamiliae, Katerocrinidae n. fam.,
   Katerocrinus indicus n. gen., n. comb. This extends the range of the
   bifascial dendrocrinids upward into the Permian. ?Ulocrinus conoideus
   has trifascial radial facets and is assigned to the superfamily
   Scytalocrinoidea, incertae familiae, Dochmocrinus conoideus n. gen., n.
   comb. It re-emphasizes the need for revision of the family
   Scytalocrinidae. An unnamed, poorly preserved cup is described and
   considered to be a pelecocrinid crinoid, thus adding to the diversity of
   the West Timor Permian crinoids. [copyright] 2012 Elsevier B.V. and
   Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, CAS. All rights
   reserved.
C1 Webster, G.D.; Washington State Univ, Sch Earth & Environm Sci, Pullman,
   WA 99164, USA, USA.
EM webster@wsu.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1871-174X

   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods;
   Palaeozoic

   distribution; systematics] [Permian /  / ]. 
   Dochmocrinus; Kraterocrinus [Permian /  / New genus]. 
   Kraterocrinidae [Permian /  / New family].

   Dochmocrinus (Crinoidea): [Gen nov, Of superfamily Scytalocrinoidea,
   family Incertae sedis, Type species Ulocrinus? conoideus Wanner 1937, p.
   112, Permian; Fossil]. 
   Dochmocrinus conoideus - (Wanner 1937) (Crinoidea): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Ulocrinus, p. 113]. 
   Kraterocrinidae (Crinoidea): [Fam nov, Of order Dendrocrinida,
   superfamily Incertae sedis, Type genus Kraterocrinus, p. 110, Permian;
   Fossil]. 
   Kraterocrinus (Crinoidea): [Gen nov, Of new family Kraterocrinidae, Type
   species Ulocrinus? indicus Wanner 1924, p. 110, Permian; Fossil].

   for new genus, Kraterocrinus, p. 110; Fossil].

PT J

DT Article
TI Cenozoic fossil nautiloids (Cephalopoda) from Kutch, western India.
AU Halder, Kalyan (halder_k@yahoo.co.in) 
SO Palaeoworld
VL 21
IS 2
PS 116-130
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Cenozoic marine succession of Kutch, India, is rich in benthic
   molluscs and other invertebrates, but nautiloids are very scanty. Three
   nautiloid species, with two being new, are reported here:
   Deltoidonautilus vredenburgi n. sp. from the Early Eocene Naredi
   Formation, Cimomia forbesi (d'Archiac and Haime, 1854) from the Middle
   Eocene Harudi Formation, and Aturia gujaratensis n. sp. from the Early
   Miocene Khari Nadi and Chhasra formations. Taphonomic and sedimentary
   features reveal that the Eocene nautiloids were parautochthonous whereas
   the Miocene species might have been transported post-mortally for some
   distance. Palaeobiogeographic distribution of the Cenozoic nautiloids of
   the Indian subcontinent and other parts of the world reveals that though
   the genera are pandemic the species are often endemic to a basin or a
   province. Specific endemism and pattern of broad faunal similarity of
   nautiloids among different provinces within the Tethys Realm (sensu
   Harzhauser et al., 2002) mimic those of the benthic molluscs during the
   Palaeogene. [copyright] 2012 Elsevier B.V. and Nanjing Institute of
   Geology and Palaeontology, CAS. All rights reserved.
C1 Halder, Kalyan; Presidency Univ, Dept Geol, 86-1 Coll St, Kolkata 70073,
   India, India.
EM halder_k@yahoo.co.in
SC Zoology
SN 1871-174X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Aturia gujaratensis [Gujarat /  / New species]. 
   Cimomia forbesi [Gujarat / Kutch, Harudi Formation / distribution;
   systematics] [Eocene / Middle Eocene / ]. 
   Deltoidonautilus vredenburgi [Gujarat /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Nautiloidea
OR Aturia gujaratensis (Nautiloidea): [Sp nov, Gujarat, P. 125; Fossil]. 
   Cimomia forbesi - (d'Archaic &  Haime 1854) (Nautiloidea): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 122; Fossil]. 
   Deltoidonautilus vredenburgi (Nautiloidea): [Sp nov, Gujarat, Eocene, P.
   118; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Mexican species of Exetastes (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae: Banchinae),
   with description of three new species.
AU Khalaim, Andrey I. (ptera@mail.ru) 
   Ruiz-Cancino, Enrique
SO Revista Mexicana de Biodiversidad
VL 83
IS 2
PS 370-379
PD junio 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Twenty one species and subspecies of Exetastes Gray, are recorded from
   Mexico. Exetastes arteagus sp. nov., E. gauldi sp. nov. and E. lascivus
   sp. nov. are described as new. Exetastes pasculus Gauld et Ugalde is
   recorded for the first time for Mexico. New data on distribution in
   Mexico and a key to the Mexican species of Exetastes are provided. The
   known Mexican fauna is closer to the Nearctic fauna than to the Costa
   Rican fauna: 13 out of 21 Mexican species and subspecies (62%) also
   occur in the USA and Canada, 4 species (19%) also occur in Costa Rica,
   and 3 species and 1 subspecies (19%) are known from Mexico only. The
   most abundant species of the genus in Mexico is E. tarsalis.
C1 Khalaim, Andrey I.; Univ Autonoma Tamaulipas, Fac Ingn & Ciencias, Cd
   Victoria, Tamaulipas 87149, Mexico, Mexico.
EM ptera@mail.ru

DT Article
TI Two new species of the bee genus Peponapis, with a key to the North and
   Central American species (Hymenoptera: Apidae: Eucerini).
AU Ayala, Ricardo (rayala@ibiologia.unam.mx) 
   Griswold, Terry
SO Revista Mexicana de Biodiversidad
VL 83
IS 2
PS 396-406
PD junio 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 3
U2 10
AB Two new species of squash bees, Peponapis pacifica Ayala and Griswold
   sp. n. and P parkeri Griswold and Ayala sp. n., are described and
   illustrated. Peponapis pacifica is oligolectic on flowers of
   Schizocarpum longisepalum (Cucurbitaceae) endemic to Mexico, where it is
   found in the tropical dry forest along the Pacific Coast, between Sonora
   and Chiapas and in the Balsas River basin; and P parkeri is known only
   from the Pacific slope of Costa Rica. A key for the North and Central
   American species of Peponapis is provided.

DT Article
TI Metazoan parasites of Tlacuatzin canescens and Marmosa mexicana
   (Mammalia: Didelphimorphia) from Mexico.
FT Metazoarios parasitos de Tlacuatzin canescens y Marmosa mexicana
   (Mammalia: Didelphimorphia) de Mexico.
AU Guzman-Cornejo, Carmen
   Garcia-Prieto, Luis (gprieto@ibiologia.unam.mx) 
   Acosta-Gutierrez, Roxana
   Falcon-Ordaz, Jorge
   Leon-Paniagua, Livia
SO Revista Mexicana de Biodiversidad
VL 83
IS 2
PS 557-561
PD junio 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 5
AB As a part of an ongoing project to inventory the metazoan parasites of
   Mexican mammals, 4 specimens of 2 species of mouse opossums (2
   Tlacuatzin canescens (Allen, 1893) and 2 Marmosa mexicana Merriam,
   1897), were collected from Oaxaca and Veracuz states, Mexico,
   respectively. Five new locality and host records are presented for the
   Acari Ixodes luciae Senevet, 1940, Ixodes sinaloa Kohls and Clifford,
   1966, of fleas Plusaetis mathesoni (Traub 1950), and Polygenis
   martinezbaezi Vargas 1951, as well as the cestode Hymenolepis sp., while
   the nematode Hoineffia simplicispicula Navone, Suriano and Pujol, 1991,
   is recorded for the first time in Mexico.

DT Article
TI Systematics and phylogeography of the steppe whiskered bat Myotis
   aurascens Kuzyakin, 1935 (Chiroptera, Vespertilionidae).
AU Tsytsulina, Katerina (tsytsulina@hotmail.com) 
   Dick, Matthew H.
   Maeda, Kishio
   Masuda, Ryuichi
SO Russian Journal of Theriology
VL 11
IS 1
PS 1-20
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 2
U2 7
AB Phylogenetic relationships were examined among specimens identified as
   Myotis aurascens Kuzyakin, 1935 from across their distribution (Europe
   to the Korean Peninsula), and also among M. aurascens and other Myotis
   species. Phylogenetic reconstructions were based upon sequences of the
   mitochondrial cytochrome b and ND1 genes. In the cytochrome b analysis,
   the specimens identified as M. aurascens on the basis of morphology
   emerged as a polyphyletic group (referred to as clades A, B and C).
   Genetic data supported the status of clade A, which comprised most of
   the sequences, as a species distinct from M. mystacinus and the other
   species analysed. A paratype specimen of the form sogdianus Kuzyakin,
   1934 appeared in the clade A of Myotis aurascens, which suggested
   clearly that they belong to the same species. However, despite that
   sogdianus Kuzyakin, 1934 should be considered a senior synonym of
   aurascens Kuzyakin, 1935, taking into consideration that a paratype does
   not have a name-baring function, we do not suggest to make any changes
   in the species name Myotis aurascens till further studies. In the
   morphometric analysis, M. aurascens showed a clinal pattern of variation
   in cranial length and most correlated measurements, which appears to be
   mostly independent from the mitochondrial gene patterns. Myotis
   nipalensis przewalskii appeared separately, with large genetic distances
   from M. mystacinus and the main M. aurascens clade. Our analysis
   suggests that because of the morphological similarity between M.
   aurascens, M. nipalensis, and the light coloured M. mystacinus
   throughout most of their distribution, identification of M. aurascens
   should be made on the basis of morphological characters, while in Europe
   and the Tien Shan Mountains region identifications should be made based
   on genetic data.
C1 Tsytsulina, Katerina; Vertebrate Research Division, National Institute
   of Biological Resources, Gyoungseo-dong, Seo-gu, Incheon 404-708, South
   Korea, South Korea.
EM tsytsulina@hotmail.com
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1682-3559
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Genetics; Evolution;
   Variation; Morphological variation; Zoogeography; Land zones
DE Myotis aurascens [Molecular genetics / Cytb & ND1 sequence diversity /
   taxonomic implications] [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / ] [Biochemical
   variation /  / ] [Size variation / Cranial length variation / ]
   [Zoogeography /  / ] [Palaearctic region /  / distribution]. 
TN Bats; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Chiroptera, Vespertilionidae
OR Myotis aurascens - Kuzyakin 1935 (Vespertilionidae): [Syn nov, Myotis
   mongolius Kruskop & Borissenko 1996, p. 13; Syn nov, Myotis pamirensis
   Kuzyakin 1935, p. 13; Syn nov, Myotis popovi Strelkov 1983, p. 13;
   Status, Species status support, p. 12]. 
   Myotis nipalensis - (Benda &  Tsytsulina 2000) (Vespertilionidae):
   [Status, Species status support, p. 13].

DT Article
TI A review of continental species of Phrudocentra Warren, 1895
   (Lepidoptera: Geometridae, Geometrinae).
AU Viidalepp, J. (jaan.viidalepp@emu.ee) 
   Lindt, A.
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 40
IS 158
PS 171-190
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A key to continental Neotropical species of Phrudocentra Warren, 1895,
   s. lat. is designed and provided with photos of moths and their male
   genital structures. The genus Phrudocentra Warren is redefined. Two
   subgenera are reinstated within Phrudocentra Warren, s. lat.:
   Phrudocentra Warren, s. str. (type species: P. pupillata Warren, 1897)
   and Melochlora Warren, 1901 (type species: Tachyphyle neis Druce, 1892).
   Three new genera are described: Assachlora Viidalepp&Lindt, gen. n.
   (type species: Nemoria assa Druce, 1892), Lindachlora Viidalepp&Lindt,
   gen. n. (type species: Tachyphyle flaccida Warren, 1909) and Lissocentra
   Viidalepp&Lindt, gen. n. (type species: Melochlora hydatodes Warren,
   1906). Two species are found fitting with characters of the genus
   Lissochlora Warren, 1900: Lissochlora niveiceps (Prout, 1912) comb. n.
   and Lissochlora senescens (Prout, 1917) comb. n. One new species,
   Assachlora julietae Viidalepp&Lindt, sp. n. is described.
C1 Viidalepp, J.; Estonian Univ Life Sci, Inst Agron & Environm Studies,
   Riia St 181, Tartu, EE-51014, Estonia, Estonia.

DT Article
TI Kasyniana shardana Baldizzone, sp n. (Lepidoptera: Oecophoridae).
AU Baldizzone, G. (giorgiobaldizzone@tin.it) 
   Landry, J.-F.
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 40
IS 158
PS 197-205
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB This work describes Kasyniana shardana Baldizzone, sp. n., a species
   discovered in Sardinia. It closely resembles K. diminutella (Rebel,
   1931) which occurs in continental Europe. The two species can be
   distinguished by their colouration, differences in male and female
   genitalia, and DNA barcode sequences (mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase
   I, or COI gene).

TI Systematics and Faunistics of Neotropical Grapholitini, 1: Dichrorampha
   Guenee, 1845 (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae).
AU Razowski, J. (Razowski@isez.pan.krakow.pl) 
   Becker, V.O.
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 40
IS 158
PS 207-224
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Eigtheen species of Neotropical Dichrorampha (D. obliqua
   Razowski&Becker, sp. n., D. brusquaea Razowski&Becker, sp. n., D.
   mnesisocia Razowski&Becker, sp. n., D. atomosa Razowski&Becker, sp. n.,
   D. limae Razowski&Becker, sp. n., D. horata Razowski&Becker, sp. n., D.
   rhaphidagus Razowski&Becker, sp. n., D. telaria Razowski&Becker, sp. n.,
   D. phoreosocia Razowski&Becker, sp. n., D. ischyros Razowski&Becker, sp.
   n., D. albicans Razowski&Becker, sp. n., D. brevis Razowski&Becker, sp.
   n., D. ochripalpana Razowski&Becker, sp. n., D. laevigata
   Razowski&Becker, sp. n., D. loncheres Razowski&Becker, sp. n., D.
   ipameriae Razowski&Becker, sp. n., D. deindentata Razowski&Beckek, sp.
   n., D. opipara Razowski&Becker, sp. n.) and the unknown female of one
   species (Dichrorampha chloantha Razowski) are described. History of
   studies and systematics of Dichrorampha are discussed.

TI Additional data on the Phyllonorycter haasi-group with description of
   two new species (Lepidoptera: Gracillariidae).
AU Lastuvka, Z. (last@mendelu.cz) 
   Lastuvka, A.
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 40
IS 158
PS 231-239
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the Phyllonorycter haasi-group are described:
   Phyllonorycter balansae Lastuvka&Lastuvka, sp. n. from Spain, living on
   Cytisus balansae and Ph. floridae Lastuvka&Lastuvka, sp. n. from
   Portugal, living on Genista florida. The diagnostic characters of all
   species of the group are defined. New faunistic and biological
   observations are presented, and several previous data are corrected. All
   important morphological characters (adults, male and female genitalia)
   are figured.

TI A New Nearctic Species of Boletina Staeger Fungus Gnat (Diptera:
   Mycetophilidae).
AU Taber, Stephen W.
SO Southwestern Entomologist
VL 37
IS 2
PS 159-170
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A second new species of Boletina Staeger fungus gnat was discovered in
   western Michigan following the discovery of Boletina michigana Taber in
   the same habitat at the same time of year. Males and females were
   collected in early spring in a Malaise trap in a paper birch (Betula
   papyrifera Marshall)-red maple (Acer rubrum L.)-black cherry (Prunus
   serotina Ehrhart) woods adjacent to black ash (Fraxinus nigra Marshall)
   swamp and cattail (Typha latifolia L.) marsh. Boletina setacea Taber
   will key out to Boletina sciarina Staeger by using one of two old keys,
   but male terminalia and wing venation indicated a specific difference.
C1 Taber, Stephen W.; Saginaw Valley State Univ, Dept Biol, 7400 Bay Rd,
   University Ctr, MI, 48710, USA, USA.
SC Zoology
SN 0147-1724
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA

DT Article
TI GAEOLAELAPS CARABIDOPHILUS N. SP., A NEW MITE SPECIES (ACARI:
   MESOSTIGMATA: LAELAPIDAE) FROM CARABID BEETLES (COLEOPTERA: CARABIDAE)
   FROM SOUTHERN UKRAINE.
AU Trach, Viacheslav A. (listoed@rambler.ru) 
SO Acarologia (Paris)
VL 52
IS 2
PS 157-163
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Gaeolaelaps carabidophilus n. sp., a new laelapine mite (Acari:
   Mesostigmata: Laelapidae) is described and illustrated based on females
   collected from Stenolophus mixtus (Herbst, 1784) (Coleoptera: Carabidae)
   on the north-western Black Sea coast (Ukraine, Odessa province). The new
   species differs from all congeners by the following combination of
   characters: dorsal soft cuticle hypertrichous, very short peritremes
   (reaching only to mid-coxa III), dorsal shield with only 39 pairs of
   setae, sternal shield with 3 pairs of lyrifissures.
C1 Trach, Viacheslav A.; II Mechnikov Odessa Natl Univ, Dept Zool,
   Shampanskij Al 2, Odessa, UA-65058, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM listoed@rambler.ru
RI Trach, Viacheslav/C-7465-2018
OI Trach, Viacheslav/0000-0002-4888-0153
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0044-586X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Associations; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

   (Coleoptera) / New associate species] [Ukraine /  / New species;
   coleopteran associate]. 
   Stenolophus mixtus [Associations / Gaeolaelaps carabidophilus
   (Arachnida) / New associate species] [Ukraine /  / New associated
   arachnid species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Beetles; Chelicerates; Insects; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI THE ORIBATID MITE GENUS CERATORCHESTES (ACARI: ORIBATIDA: PELOPPIIDAE).
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Kaluz, Stanislav
SO Acarologia (Paris)
VL 52
IS 2
PS 165-172
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The neotropical oribatid mite genus Ceratorchestes comprises four
   species. A new subgenus, Ceratorchestes (Paraceratorchestes) n. subgen.,
   is proposed. It is distinguishable from the nominate subgenus,
   Ceratorchestes (Ceratorchestes), by the length of the epimeres III + IV
   and the localization of setae on epimere IV. A new species,
   Ceratorchestes (Paraceratorchestes) variabilis n. sp., is described and
   illustrated. The morphology of the gnathosoma and legs is presented and
   represents the first such data for a member of this genus. An
   identification key to all known species of Ceratorchestes is given.
C1 Ermilov, Sergey G.; Fed Serv Vet & Phytosanit Inspect, Nizhniy Novgorod
   Referral Ctr, Gagarin 97, Nizhniy Novgorod 603107, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0044-586X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Ceratorchestes (Paraceratorchestes) variabilis [Ecuador /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari

DT Article
TI AN UPDATED STUDY OF PTYCTIMOUS MITE FAUNA (ACARI: ORIBATIDA) OF THE
   AUSTRALASIAN REGION WITH A DESCRIPTION OF THIRTEEN NEW SPECIES.
AU Niedbala, Wojciech (wojciech.niedbala@amu.edu.pl) 
SO Acarologia (Paris)
VL 52
IS 2
PS 183-228
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This paper presents a review of 91 ptyctimous oribatid mite species
   including three Mesoplophoridae, 25 Euphthiracaroidea and 63 of
   Phthiracaroidea of the Australasian Region. Thirteen species are new for
   science: c (Mesoplophora) parapulchra n. sp., Apoplophora paraserrata n.
   sp., Acrotritia paraspiculifera n. sp., Microtritia cristata n. sp.,
   Plonaphacarus vicinus n. sp., Steganacarus (Rhacaplacarus) cucullus n.
   sp., Austrophthiracarus konwerskii n. sp., Arphthicarus trivestigius n.
   sp., Notophthiracarus angustus n. sp., Notophthiracarus bloszyki n. sp.,
   Notophthiracarus hallidayi n. sp., Notophthiracarus lewisensis n. sp.,
   Notophthiracarus parausitatus n. sp. Descriptions of eight known species
   are also provided with some morphological remarks. New localities have
   been discovered for 46 species extending their hitherto geographical
   ranges. Twenty-four species, considered until now as endemics to one
   locality, are reported from new localities. The greatest number of
   endemic mites has been found in southern Australia, in particular in the
   State of Victoria. The present ptyctimous fauna of the Australasian
   Region comprises now 240 species, including one Protoplophoridae, eight
   Mesoplophoridae, 49 Euphthiracaroidea and 182 Phthiracaroidea. Almost
   all genera of the group are reported from this region. The largest
   number of ptyctimous mite species has been found in Queensland and New
   South Wales. The highest number of species is found in two
   Phthiracaroidea genera: Notophthiracarus and Austrophthiracarus. Within
   the Euphthiracaroidea, the highest number of species has been observed
   in the genera Oribotritia and Acrotritia.
C1 Niedbala, Wojciech; Adam Mickiewicz Univ, Fac Biol, Umultowska 89,
   Poznan, PL-61614, Poland, Poland.
EM wojciech.niedbala@amu.edu.pl
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0044-586X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Biometrics; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Acrotritia paraspiculifera; Apoplophora paraserrata; Arphthicarus
   trivestigius; Plonaphacarus vicinus [Queensland /  / New species]. 
   Apoplophora pantotrema [Papua New Guinea / Mount Kaindi & Wau / New
   record]. 
   Austrophthiracarus konwerskii; Mesoplophora (Mesoplophora) parapulchra;
   Microtritia cristata; Notophthiracarus angustus; Notophthiracarus
   bloszyki; Notophthiracarus lewisensis; Notophthiracarus parausitatus;
   Steganacarus (Rhacaplacarus) cucullus [New South Wales /  / New
   species]. 
   Notophthiracarus hallidayi [Australian Capital Territory /  / New
   species]. 
   Oribatida [Biometrics /  / New record; systematics; records] [Australia
   /  / distribution]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari

   Apoplophora pantotrema (Acari): [New record].

DT Article
TI Clausiliidae of Guangxi, southern China (Gastropoda, Pulmonata,
   Stylommatophora).
AU Nordsieck, Hartmut (hnords@t-online.de) 
SO Acta Conchyliorum
VL 12
PS 3-55
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The present paper is an iconography of the known clausiliid species of
   the province of Guangxi, southern China. It contains a list of the
   species and subspecies, with systematical annotations, and a
   zoogeographical analysis of the fauna. Nearly all species taxa are
   figured; most of the figured specimens are types. The following genus
   and species taxa are described as new: Phaedusinae: Nannophaedusa n.
   gen. (type species: Nannophaedusa acicula n. sp.); Acanthophaedusa
   gemrnulata n. sp.; Hemiphaedusa (Margaritiphaedusa) whitteni n. sp.; H.
   (Selenophaedusa) castanea n. sp.; H. (S.) princeps n. sp.; Nannophaedusa
   acicula n. sp.; Miraphaedusa (M.) pretiosa n. sp.; Oospira
   (Distortiphaedusa) coffea n. sp.; O. (Formosana) elegans n. sp.; O. (F.)
   malleolata n. sp.; Synprosphyma (S.) occulta n. sp.; Euphaedusa (E.)
   loczyi uniplicata n. subsp.; Hemiphaedusa (Selenophaedusa) spinifera
   hechiensis n. subsp.; Oospira (Distortiphaedusa) zhaoyifani sigridae n.
   subsp.; Phaedusa (P.) lypra duanensis n. subsp.; Garnieriinae:
   Grandinenia ignea n. sp.; G. magnilabris n. sp.; G. puella n. sp.; G.
   unicolor n. sp.; G. rulinensis n. sp.; G. fuchsi pseudotigris n. subsp.;
   G. maroskoi gigantea n. subsp.; G. pallidissima albescens n. subsp.; G.
   pseudofuchsi nigrofasciata n. subsp.; G. p. remota n. subsp.; G. p.
   varicolor n. subsp.; Tropidauchenia dorri adusta n. subsp.; T. d.
   adustella n. subsp.

DT Article
TI CICADIVETTA GOUMENISSA, A NEW CICADA SPECIES FROM PELOPONESOS, GREECE
   (HEMIPTERA: CICADIDAE).
AU Gogala, Matija (matija.gogala@guest.arnes.si) 
   Drosopoulos, Sakis
   Trilar, Tomi
SO Acta Entomologica Slovenica
VL 20
IS 1
PS 5-16
PD Junij 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Near the village of Goumenissa, Peloponesos, Greece, we heard and
   recorded an unusual and unknown cicada song in the years 2005 and 2006.
   It was high pitched, hardly audible to humans and therefore we had to
   use ultrasonic detectors. Later we collected some specimens and found
   out that it is an undescribed species. Here we publish a description of
   this new taxon with the name Cicadivetta goumenissa sp. n. In addition
   to morphological characteristics this species is distinguished by a song
   pattern with very fast sequences of short echemes (SE, duration 26[plus
   or minus]7 ms) of different duration (a few SE up to more than 500 and
   37 s duration and repetition frequency of 13-22 SE/s), followed by
   single long echemes (LE, duration: 535[plus or minus]88 ms).
   Exceptionally there are sequences with longer LE echemes (760[plus or
   minus]284 ms) and without or just a few SE in-between.
C1 Gogala, Matija; Slovenian Academy of Sciences and Arts, Novi trg 3,
   SI-1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia, Slovenia.
EM matija.gogala@guest.arnes.si
SC Zoology
SN 1318-1998
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Cicadivetta goumenissa [Greece /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Cicadoidea, Cicadidae
OR Cicadivetta (Cicadidae): [Key to species, Acoustic & morphological keys,
   p. 14]. 
   Cicadivetta goumenissa (Cicadidae): [Sp nov, Greece, P. 7].
