DT Article
TI A new species of Euryhaliotrematoides Plaisance & Kritsky, 2004
   (Monogenea: Dactylogyridae) from the gills of the spotted rose snapper
   Lutjanus guttatus (Steindachner) (Perciformes: Lutjanidae).
AU Soler-Jimenez, Lilia C.
   Garcia-Gasca, Alejandra
   Fajer-Avila, Emma J. (catesoler@yahoo.com) 
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 82
IS 2
PS 113-119
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB n. sp. (Monogenea: Dactylogyridae) is described based on specimens
   collected from the gills of the spotted rose snapper (Steindachner) off
   Mazatlan, Sinaloa, on the northwestern coast of Mexico. The synapomorphy
   of this genus is the presence of a funnel-shaped base of the male
   copulatory organ. This new species differs from all other species of the
   genus by possessing a male copulatory organ with a base with a thickened
   margin and a membranous accessory piece resembling a scarf and covering
   about 60% of its distal region. PCR products of the 28S rRNA (831 bp)
   and 18S rRNA (662 bp) genes were sequenced and submitted to GenBank
   (accession numbers HQ615997 and JF938069, respectively). BLASTn searches
   revealed no 100% identical hits with the previously registered
   monogenean sequences.
C1 Fajer-Avila, Emma J.; Ctr Invest Alimentac & Desarrollo AC, Lab
   Parasitol, Ave Sabalo Cerritos S-N, Mazatlan, Sinaloa, 82010, Mexico,
   Mexico.

DT Article
TI Description of a new species of Eimeria Schneider, 1875 (Apicomplexa:
   Eimeriidae) from the western Derby eland Taurotragus derbianus derbianus
   Gray (Artiodactyla: Bovidae) in Senegal.
AU Maca, Ondrej (biola.biola@seznam.cz) 
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 82
IS 2
PS 121-123
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Examination of faecal samples from semicaptive western Derby elands
   Gray, in the Bandia and Fathala Reserves of Senegal, revealed the
   presence of oocysts of the genus Schneider, 1875 that we considered to
   represent a new species, n. sp. The new species possesses nearly
   ellipsoidal oocysts (length/width ratio 1.3) with a bi-layered wall and
   an average size of 27.6 x 21.5 [mu]m. possesses a micropyle covered by a
   micropylar cap and ovoidal, single-layered sporocysts with an average
   size of 14.9 x 7.7 [mu]m, each with a Stieda body. Sporozoites of
   possess a large refractile body and a nucleus. Sporulation lasted for 2
   days at 23[degree]C. The new species is differentiated from the two
   species parasitising Pallas, Triffitt, 1924 and Yakimoff, 1934.
C1 Maca, Ondrej; State Vet Inst Prague, Dept Pathol & Parasitol, Sidlistni
   136-24, Prague, 16503 6, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM biola.biola@seznam.cz
OI Maca, Ondrej/0000-0002-6311-0851

TI Sciadicleithrum juruparii n. sp (Monogenea: Ancyrocephalidae) from the
   gills of Satanoperca jurupari (Heckel) (Osteichthyes: Cichlidae) in the
   Guama River, Amazon Delta, Brazil.
AU Carvalho de Melo, Marly de Fatima
   dos Santos, Jeannie Nascimento
   Santos, Claudia Portes (cpsantos@ioc.fiocruz.br) 
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 82
IS 2
PS 125-129
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB n. sp. is described from the gills of the Neotropical cichlid fish
   (Heckel) caught in the Guama River, in the delta of the Amazon River, at
   Bel,m, Para State, Brazil. Diagnostic characters of the new species are
   a basally articulated male copulatory organ with clockwise coils and an
   accessory piece; a ventral bar with a median process; similar hooklets;
   vagina in the form of a sclerotised tube; and a sinistral vaginal
   aperture with a sclerotised papilla lying in a small surface depression.
   It is the only species of Kritsky, Thatcher&Boeger, 1989 with a medial
   projection on the ventral bar.

DT Article
TI Rhabdias esculentarum n. sp. (Nematoda: Rhabdiasidae) from green frogs
   of the Rana esculenta species complex in Italy: molecular evidence,
   morphological description and genetic differentiation from its congeners
   in frogs and toads.
AU Cipriani, Paolo
   Mattiucci, Simonetta (simonetta.mattiucci@uniroma1.it) 
   Paoletti, Michela
   Santoro, Mario
   Nascetti, Giuseppe
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 82
IS 2
PS 131-146
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new taxon, n. sp., is described based on DNA sequence analysis at
   multiple loci (i.e. mtDNA, 12S rRNA, ITS-1 and partial ITS-2 regions of
   the nuclear rDNA) and morphometric analysis carried out on specimens
   collected from the green frogs of the species complex in Italy (i.e.
   Camerano and Linnaeus, identified genetically by diagnostic allozyme
   loci). n. sp. was differentiated genetically, at both mitochondrial and
   nuclear levels, from (Schrank, 1788) ( Hartwich, 1972) and Goodey, 1924
   recovered from the toad Linnaeus collected sympatrically with the
   specimens of and examined in the present study. Moreover, the new taxon
   proved to be different from the other species of from anurans, which had
   previously been sequenced using the same genes and deposited in
   GeneBank. Phylogenetic analyses (MP and ML) inferred from mitochondrial
   (mtDNA and 12S ribosomal RNA) and nuclear (ITS-1 and ITS-2 of the rDNA
   regions) sequences datasets were congruent in depicting n. sp. as
   forming a highly supported clade distinct from the sympatric species, as
   well as from, characterised on the basis of the same loci. Morphometric
   analysis and the differential diagnosis of genetically characterised
   specimens of the new species have revealed differences in several
   features in comparison with the type-species, Material of the latter
   species included voucher specimens from Germany deposited by Hartwich
   (1972) and other specimens collected from in Italy. Among the diagnostic
   characters, the particular cup-shaped buccal capsule characterising is
   clearly different from the tear-shaped buccal capsule observed in
   material of obtained from Berlin Museum and collected in the same
   geographical area as the green frogs under study. was also found to
   differ in some measurements and allometric characters from ( Moravec et
   al., 1997). The data so far collected appear to indicate a
   host-preference of for and, which belong to the hybridogenetic species
   complex in Italy.

   Moro 5, Rome, Italy, Italy.

DT Article
TI Cavearhynchus, a new genus of tapeworm (Cestoda: Trypanorhyncha:
   Pterobothriidae) from Himantura lobistoma Manjaji-Matsumoto & Last, 2006
   (Rajiformes) off Borneo, including redescriptions and new records of
   species of Pterobothrium Diesing, 1850.
AU Schaeffner, Bjoern C. (b.schaeffner@unimelb.edu.au) 
   Beveridge, Ian
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 82
IS 2
PS 147-165
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB A new genus of trypanorhynch cestode is described from the tubemouth
   whipray Manjaji-Matsumoto&Last, 2006 in the South China Sea off
   Malaysian Borneo. n. g., n. sp. possesses four pedicellate bothria in a
   cruciform arrangement, a heteroacanthous, heteromorphous metabasal
   tentacular armature with five hooks per principle row and an alternating
   longitudinal file of intercalary hooks on the bothrial surface of each
   tentacle, but lacks prebulbar organs and gland-cells within the bulbs.
   It, thus, closely resembles taxa belonging to the lacistorhynchoid
   family Pterobothriidae Pintner, 1931. However, the new genus differs
   from other genera within this family in the possession of bothrial pits.
   Although a distinguishing characteristic of the superfamily
   Otobothrioidea Dollfus, 1942, representatives of this group exhibit two
   bothria and the bothrial pits are lined with spiniform microtriches,
   whereas the pit-like structures.of n. g., n. sp. entirely lack
   microtriches. Redescriptions of two species of, namely
   Campbell&Beveridge, 1996 and . (Shipley&Hornell, 1906) Dollfus, 1930 are
   provided from material collected off Borneo and several localities off
   Australia. Moreover, new host and locality records are added for
   Campbell&Beveridge, 1996 and (Southwell, 1929) Beveridge&Campbell, 1989.

DT Article
TI Three new species of Merizocotyle Cerfontaine, 1894 (Monogenea:
   Monocotylidae) from the nasal tissues of dasyatid rays collected off
   Malaysian and Indonesian Borneo.
AU Chisholm, Leslie A. (leslie.chisholm@samuseum.sa.gov.au) 
   Whittington, Ian D.
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 82
IS 2
PS 167-176
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB Three new species of Cerfontaine, 1894 (Monogenea: Monocotylidae) are
   described from the nasal tissues of stingrays collected off Borneo. n.
   sp. is described from the dwarf whipray (Muller&Henle) collected in
   shallow waters off Sematan, Sarawak, Malaysia. This species can be
   distinguished from the other members of the genus by the morphology of
   the sclerotised male copulatory organ, which is long with many twists
   and loops. The vaginae of this species are also long and looped. n. sp.
   is described from the roughnose stingray Last, Manjaji&Yearsley
   collected off Sematan and Mukah, Sarawak, Malaysia. It is distinguished
   from the other species of by the morphology of the male copulatory
   organ, which is a sclerotised tube that expands slightly and then tapers
   at the distal end, and by the presence of papillae on the dorsal edge of
   the haptor. n. sp. is described from the whitenose whip ray (Bleeker)
   collected off Manggar, East Kalimantan, Indonesia. It can be
   differentiated by the male copulatory organ, which is a short, narrow,
   curved, sclerotised tube tapering distally, and the path of the ovary,
   which runs anteriorly to the base of the ootype. We also provide details
   of new host and/or locality records for (Beverley-Burton&Williams, 1989)
   Chisholm, Wheeler&Beverley-Burton, 1995, Beverley-Burton&Williams, 1989
   and (Hargis, 1955) Chisholm, Wheeler&Beverley-Burton, 1995.

   of Pastinachus solocirostris (Pisces), p. 170; Parasite]. 
   Merizocotyle pseudodasybatis (Monogenea): [Parasite; New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR14807052803
DT Article
TI The assassin bug genus Haematoloecha in Taiwan, with notes on species
   occurring in the neighbouring areas (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Reduviidae:
   Ectrichodiinae).
AU Redei, David (redei@nhmus.hu) 
   Tsai, Jing-Fu
SO Zootaxa
VL 3332
PS 1-26
PD 1 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3332.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03332p026.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The species of the assassin bug genus Haematoloecha Stal, 1874
   (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Reduviidae: Ectrichodiinae) occurring in Taiwan
   are surveyed. Five species are recognized, two of them, Haematoloecha
   curta sp. nov. and H. pusilla sp. nov. are described as new.
   Haematoloecha adachii Tachikawa, 1968 and H. nigrorubra Distant, 1919
   are recorded for the first time from Taiwan. Haematoloecha nigrorubra is
   recognized as having disjunct East Himalayan[long dash]Formosan dis-
   tribution pattern; a new subspecies, H. nigrorubra conspicua ssp. nov.
   is described for members of the Taiwanese popu- lation. A revised
   diagnosis of Haematoloecha is provided, species known to occur in Taiwan
   are keyed. The synonymy of H. nigriventris (Fallou, 1887) with H.
   nigrorufa (Stal, 1867) is confirmed. The colour variability of H.
   nigrorufa is discussed. The following taxonomic changes are proposed:
   Haematoloecha puetzi (Kerzhner&Gunther, 2004), comb. nov. (transferred
   from Parascadra Miller, 1954); H. nigrorubra Distant, 1919 = H. yunnana
   Hsiao&Ren, 1981, syn. nov.; H. rubescens Distant, 1883 = H. laeta
   Breddin, 1913, syn. nov. = H. laeta var. ardens Breddin, 1913, syn. nov.
   Lectotypes are designated for H. nigriventris, H. nigrorubra, H.
   nigrorufa and H. rubescens.
C1 Redei, David; Hungarian Natural History Museum, Department of Zoology,
   H-1088 Budapest, Baross u. 13, Hungary, Hungary.
EM redei@nhmus.hu

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI New records and new species of Magelonidae (Polychaeta) from the Arabian
   Peninsula, with a re-description of Magelona pacifica and a discussion
   on the magelonid buccal region.
AU Mortimer, Kate (Katie.Mortimer@museumwales.ac.uk) 
   Cassa, Susanna
   Martin, Daniel
   Gil, Joao
SO Zootaxa
VL 3331
PS 1-43
PD 1 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3331.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03331p043.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Five Magelona species, M. cornuta, M. crenulifrons, M. obockensis, M.
   pulchella, and an undescribed species (identified by Louis Amoureux as
   M. cornuta in 1983 and described herein as M. montera sp. nov.) have
   been previously reported from the seas surrounding the Arabian
   Peninsula. The present study details a further six Magelona species off
   the coasts of Iran and Qatar, collected between 1998 and 2007. Five
   species are newly recorded for the region: Magelona cf. agoensis,
   Magelona cf. cincta, M. conversa, Magelona cf. falcifera and M.
   symmetrica, and one species (M. sinbadi sp. nov.) is deemed new to
   science. A key is provided for the 15 species with verified reports
   currently known from the western Indian Ocean region. Magelona pacifica
   originally described from Panama is discussed and re-described due to
   its similarity to M. montera sp. nov. A 'buccal organ/tube' in addition
   to an everted proboscis was observed in one specimen (Magelona cf.
   agoensis) and is herein described and discussed in relation to previous
   morphological studies.
C1 Mortimer, Kate; Department of Biodiversity & Systematic Biology,
   Amgueddfa Cymru - National Museum Wales, Cathays Park, Cardiff CF10 3NP,
   Wales, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM Katie.Mortimer@museumwales.ac.uk

PT J
AN ZOOR14807052802
DT Article
TI Complementary redescription of Raja lintea Fries, 1839 (Elasmobranchii,
   Rajidae) and its revised generic assignment.
AU Stehmann, Matthias F.W. (stehmann@ichthys-fisch.info) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3331
PS 44-68
PD 1 Jun 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3331.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03331p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The generic status of many skate species has been revised during the
   past six decades by various authors having introduced new diagnostic
   morphological and anatomical characters. As a consequence, the original
   family Rajidae and its very diverse type genus Raja Linnaeus, 1758 have
   been split into several families, subfamilies, genera and subgenera
   which were in several cases provisionally established due to the lack of
   specific material required. However, quite a number of species
   originally in Raja remained incompletely studied and still assigned to
   Raja sensu lato, because, e.g., mature males were not yet available for
   studies of their relevant clasper features. One of these species is the
   northern North Atlantic Raja lintea Fries, 1839 which Stehmann (1970,
   1973) and Stehmann and Burkel (1984) could not assign definitively to
   the updated diagnosis of any revised rajid genus, because a mature male
   was not available. McEachran and Miyake (1990) and McEachran and Dunn
   (1998) reallocated Raja lintea to the subgenus/genus Dipturus
   Rafinesque, 1810, respectively, without evidence or explanation given.
   Since a mature male of R. lintea became available, the author has
   reinvestigated the species, presents here its so far unknown diagnostic
   characters of clasper morphology and skeleton, scapulocoracoid and
   pelvis, and assigns the species on this basis to the genus Rajella
   Stehmann, 1970.
C1 Stehmann, Matthias F.W.; ICHTHYS, Ichthyological Research Laboratory and
   Consultancy, Hildesheimer Weg 13, 22459 Hamburg, Germany, Germany.
EM stehmann@ichthys-fisch.info
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; General morphology; Appendages; Skeletal and supporting
   structures
DE Rajella lintea [Gonopod / Clasper morphology / Taxonomic implications]
   [Skeleton /  / Morphology]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Chondrichthyes, Elasmobranchii,
   Rajiformes, Rajidae
OR Dipturus linteus - (Fries 1839) (Rajidae): [Referred to, Rajella, p.
   46]. 
   Rajella lintea - (Fries 1839) (Rajidae): [Description, Neonate, p. 65;
   Redescription, P. 46; Comb nov, Transferred from Dipturus, p. 46]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807052802
DA 2020-09-17
ER

TI Lenotetrops ivanovae, gen. nov., sp nov from Afghanistan (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae).
AU Danilevsky, M.L. (danilevskyml@rambler.ru) 
SO animma.x
VL 44
PS 5-8
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Lenotetrops ivanovae, gen. nov., sp. nov. is described on the base of
   two females from Afghanistan. The new genus is close to Tetrops Kirby
   1826, but bigger and wider, with thick short antennae. The species is
   characterized by red elytra with black apex, antennae with white setae
   rings of distal joints.

DT Article
TI Toritrombicula lerdthusneei (Acari, Trombiculidae): A New Species of
   Chigger Mite Collected by Suzuki's Method from Iriomotejima Island,
   Okinawa, Japan, with Host and Distribution Records of the Genus
   Toritrombicula Sasa, 1954.
AU Takahashi, Mamoru (m.takahashi@wish.ocn.ne.jp) 
   Misumi, Hitoko
   Takahashi, Yumi
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
VL 38
IS 2
PS 53-64
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe and illustrate a new species, Toritrombicula lerdthusneei
   (Acari, Trombiculidae) and summarize the host and distribution records
   of the chiggers of the genus Toritrombicula Sasa, 1954. The type
   material was collected by Suzuki's method using black cloth from the
   coral reef of Iriomotejima Island, southwestern Okinawa, Japan. The new
   species is closely related to T. nihoaensis and T. gygis, but may be
   distinguished by the shape and size of the scutum, and the arrangement
   of the dorsal setae. Our description of a new species increases the
   total number of Toritrombicula species to 18 (15 from Asia and
   Australia, 2 from the Hawaiian Islands, and 1 from Russia).
C1 Takahashi, Mamoru; Saitama Med Univ, Dept Anesthesiol, Moroyama,
   Saitama, 3500495, Japan, Japan.
EM m.takahashi@wish.ocn.ne.jp
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1881-9052

   diseases and disorders; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   /  / distribution]. 
   Toritrombicula lerdthusneei [Japan /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari

TI Arge aruncus n. sp. (Hymenoptera, Argidae) Feeding on Aruncus dioicus in
   Japan.
AU Hara, Hideho (hara-hideho@hro.or.jp) 
   Shinohara, Akihiko
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
VL 38
IS 2
PS 75-87
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Arge aruncus n. sp. is described from Hokkaido and Honshu, Japan. The
   larvae are gregarious leaf feeders on Aruncus dioicus (Walter) Fernald
   var. kamtschaticus (Maxim.) H. Hara. Descriptions of the immature stages
   and life history are also given. Arge aruncus is a multivoltine species
   with polymodal adult emergence. This is the first record of Aruncus as a
   host plant of argid sawflies.
C1 Hara, Hideho; Hokkaido Res Org, Forestry Res Inst Doto Stn, Shintoku,
   Hokkaido, 0810038, Japan, Japan.

AB A new discolomatid species, Fallia iviei Cline and Shockley, new
   species, is described from the Dominican Republic. A distribution map,
   habitus and character images, and discussion of its biology are
   provided. The new species represents the first known member of the genus
   from the West Indies. A species checklist for all nine described species
   of Fallia Sharp is presented.

   USA, USA.

AN ZOOR14911054459
PM 25177045
DT Article
TI DESCRIPTION OF A NEW GENUS AND SPECIES OF STYGOBIONTIC DIVING BEETLE,
   PSYCHOPOMPORUS FELIPI JEAN, TELLES, AND MILLER (COLEOPTERA: DYTISCIDAE:
   HYDROPORINAE), FROM THE EDWARDS-TRINITY AQUIFER SYSTEM OF TEXAS, USA.
AU Jean, April (ajtafoya@unm.edu) 
   Telles, Nicole D.
   Gibson, J. Randy
   Foley, Dan
   Miller, Kelly B.
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 66
IS 2
PS 105-110
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Psychopomporus felipi Jean, Telles, and Miller, new genus and new
   species (Coleoptera: Dytiscidae), is described from San Felipe Springs,
   Val Verde County, Texas, USA, which emerges from the Edwards-Trinity
   aquifer system. Psychopomporus felipi shows several features typical of
   subterranean diving beetles, such as depigmentation, compound eyes
   reduced, elytra fused, and flight wings absent. Psychopomporus differs
   from other hydroporine genera in having a broad elytral epipleuron, the
   prosternal process small and with a medial, strongly produced
   prominence, and the meso- and (to a lesser extent) protibia apically
   broadly expanded and medially distinctly curved. This is the fourth
   stygobiontic diving beetle described from the Edwards-Trinity aquifer
   system in south-central Texas, USA.
C1 Jean, April; Univ New Mexico, Dept Earth & Planetary Sci, Albuquerque,
   NM, 87131, USA, USA.
EM ajtafoya@unm.edu
RI Miller, Kelly/I-6651-2012
SC Zoology
SN 0010-065X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA
DE Psychopomporus felipi [Texas /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Dytiscidae
OR Psychopomporus - Jean, Telles & Miller 2012 (Dytiscidae): [Gen nov, Of
   subfamily Hydroporinae, Type species Psychopomporus felipi Jean, Telles
   & Miller 2012, p. 106]. 
   Psychopomporus felipi - Jean, Telles & Miller 2012 (Dytiscidae): [Sp
   nov, Texas, P. 106].

DT Article
TI FIRST REPORTED OCCURRENCE OF HOPLOPYGA THOMSON, 1880 (COLEOPTERA:
   SCARABAEIDAE: CETONIINAE: GYMNETINI) FROM THE WEST INDIES, WITH
   DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES.
AU Ratcliffe, Brett C. (bratcliffe1@unl.edu) 
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 66
IS 2
PS 111-115
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Hoplopyga antilliana Ratcliffe, new species, is described from Grenada
   and Union Island in the Lesser Antilles. It resembles Hoplopyga liturata
   (Olivier) from Central and South America and is distinguished from that
   species. Species of Hoplopyga Thomson are known from Mexico to
   Argentina, but this species represents the first known occurrence for
   the genus in the West Indies.

   68588, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI CALOMICRUS JUNGCHANGI LEE AND BEENEN (COLEOPTERA: CHRYSOMELIDAE:
   GALERUCINAE), A NEW SPECIES FROM TAIWAN, WITH REDESCRIPTION OF A SIMILAR
   SPECIES, MONOLEPTA RUFOFULVA CHUJO, 1938.
AU Lee, Chi-Feng (chifeng@tari.gov.tw) 
   Beenen, Ron
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 66
IS 2
PS 123-130
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB Calomicrus jungchangi Lee and Beenen, new species, is described, and a
   similar species, Monolepta rufofulva Chujo, 1938, is redescribed and a
   lectotype designated. Male and female reproductive systems are
   illustrated in detail. Calomicrus jungchangi is easily distinguished
   from other Taiwanese members of Calomicrus Dillwyn by its characteristic
   color. It inhabits marine shorelines, probably because of its close
   association with its host plant, Ipomoea pes-caprae subspecies
   brasiliensis (L.) van Ooststr.
C1 Lee, Chi-Feng; Taiwan Agr Res Inst, Appl Zool Div, 189 Chung Cheng Rd,
   Taichung, 413, Taiwan, Taiwan.

   MEXICO AND DESCRIPTION OF THE FEMALE OF CYCLOCEPHALA BERTI DELGADO.

   Delgado, Leonardo
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 66
IS 2
PS 139-142
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Cyclocephala mesophylla Mora-Aguilar and Delgado, new species, from the
   cloud forests in Oaxaca and Veracruz, Mexico is described and
   illustrated. The new species is compared with Cyclocephala batesi
   Delgado and Castaneda, and modifications of Endrodi's key to species in
   the genus are provided in order to include this new species. The
   previously unknown female of Cyclocephala berti Delgado is described.

DT Article
TI The Faluns de Hautteville Bocage Biozone (Middle Eocene. Cotentin Basin,
   Manche county, France). IV. - The Cypraeoidea (Mollusca,
   Caenogastropoda).
FT La Biozone des Faluns de Hautteville-Bocage (Eocene du Cotentin,
   France). Iv. - les Cypraeoidea (Mollusca, Caenogastropoda).
AU Gain, Olivier
   Le Renard, Jacques
   Belliard, Laurent
SO Cossmanniana Hors-Serie
VL 5
PS 199-269
PD Juin 2012
PY 2012
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this revision of the CYPRAEOIDEA (Mollusca, Caenogastropoda) from the
   Faluns de Hautteville-Bocage Biozone, the nomenclatural status of 16
   species level taxa is fixed: Proadusta spirata (Defr.) (neotype fixed),
   Proadusta subrostrata (Gray) (neotype fixed), Proadusta procerior n.
   sp., Proadusta francki n. sp., Eocypraea gibbosula n. sp., Cypraedia
   elegans (Defr. in Sow.) (neotype fixed), Cypraedia bouilloni n. sp.,
   Cypraedia yolandae n. sp., Eucypraedia gervillii (Sow.) (lectotype
   fixed), Eucypraedia tessonorum n. sp., Eucypraedia brasili brasili (C. &
   P.) (neotype fixed), Eucypraedia brasili radius n. subsp., Eucypraedia
   georgii georgii (Defr.) (neotype fixed), Eucypraedia georgii metula n.
   subsp., Eucypraedia stab n. sp., and Eucypraedia (Pacaudia) expolita n.
   sp. (n. subgen.). Each of these taxa is described, discussed and
   figured. Similar approach is achieved for a specifically not yet
   identified taxon: Eocypraea cf. dollfusi (de Laubriere). Two new
   species, Cypraedia concinna and Cypraedia coartata, ex "Cypraea elegans"
   auct., are described from the Paris Basin Lutetian.

DT Article
TI A new species in the genus Crossodonthina (Collembola: Neanuridae) from
   China.
AU Jiang, Jigang (jigangnanjing@163.com) 
   Zhang, Shaobing
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 34
IS 2
PS 89-95
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Crossodonthina Yosii, 1954 is introduced and the diagnosis of
   the genus is provided. A new Chinese species, Crossodonthina choui, from
   Hunan Province is described. The new species can be separated from all
   known species by having a unique mandible and s-setae formula. The
   mandible consists of 5 branches and 3 basal teeth (one tooth is
   finger-like). The s-setae formula of the new species is 2+ms, 2/1, 1, 1,
   2, 1.
C1 Jiang, Jigang; College of Life Science and Technology, Central South
   University of Forestry and Technology, 498 South Shaoshan Road,
   Changsha, Hunan 410004, China, China.

   Guangdong Province, China, is described. It is similar to C. (J.) javana

DT Article
TI A new species in the subgenus Chorthippus (Altichorthippus) (Orthoptera:
   Arcypteridae) from Xinjiang, China.
AU Wang, Yanfeng (wyfcollege@sohu.com) 
   Zheng, Zhemin
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 34
IS 2
PS 131-136
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species Chorthippus (Altichorthippus) guozigouensis sp.nov.is
   described from the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region of China. The new
   species is similar to Ch. (Altichorthippus) charpini Chang, 1939 and Ch.
   (Altichorthippus) jishishanensis Zheng & Xie, 2000,but males differ from
   both as follows:length of fastigial foveolae about 3.00 times its width;
   antennae just not reaching the base of hind femur; apex of elytron
   extending to the posterior margin of seventh abdominal tergum; widest of
   costal area 0.67 times widest medial area; apex of hind wing extending
   to the middle of seventh abdominal tergum; anterior and posterior
   cubitus connate, cubital area obliterated; cercus reaching middle of
   epiproct; knee lobe brownish, not black; basal part of hind tibia
   brownish, not black. The type specimens are deposited in the Institute
   of Zoology, Shaanxi Normal University.
C1 Wang, Yanfeng; School of Life Sciences, Yan'an University, Yan'an,
   Shaanxi 716000, China, China.
EM wyfcollege@sohu.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7482
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China

   species].

ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria

DT Article
TI A catalogue of the species in the Oriental genus Systolederus Bolivar,
   1887 (Orthoptera: Tetrigoidea: Metrodoridae) with description of a new
   species from Jinggangshan, China.
AU Liang, Geqiu
   Jia, Fenglong (fenglongjia@yahoo.com.cn) 
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 34
IS 2
PS 141-146
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Systolederus choui sp. nov., from Jinggangshan, Jiangxi
   Province, China, is described. The new species is allied to Systolederus
   fujianensis Zheng and S. longinota Zheng, but differs in: 1) length of
   pronotum 3.7-4.1 ([male]), 5.5-6.6 ([female]) times as long as the
   portion surpassing apex of hind femur; 2) width of middle femur equal to
   width of tegmina in female; 3) length of third segment of posterior
   tarsi larger than the first. The types are deposited in the Biological
   Museum, Sun Yat-sen University. This is the thirtieth known species of
   Systolederus in the world. A catalogue of all currently recognized
   species in the genus Systolederus is given.
C1 Jia, Fenglong; Institute of Entomology, Life Science School, Sun Yat-sen
   University, West Xingang Road, Guangzhou, Guangdong 510275, China,
   China.
EM fenglongjia@yahoo.com.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7482
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Documentation; Publications; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Systolederus [Checklists / Distributional checklist of species / ]. 
   Systolederus choui [Jiangxi /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Systolederus - Bolivar 1887 (Saltatoria). 
   Systolederus choui (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Jiangxi, P. 142].

DT Article
TI A new species in the genus Ergatettix Kirby (Orthoptera: Tetrigidae)
   from Yunnan Province.
AU Lin, Liliang (zhengzhemin@163.com) 
   Ou, Xiaohong
   Zheng, Zhemin
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 34
IS 2
PS 147-152
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB One new species in the genus Ergatettix from Yunnan Province is
   described, Ergatettix longlingensis sp. nov. This new species is allied
   to Ergatettix serrifemorides Zheng & Shi, 2009, but differs in: 1)
   antenna inserted below the lower margin of eyes; 2) hind process
   reaching the apex of hind femora; 3) hind wing reaching the apex of hind
   process; 4) lateral keels of prozona constructed backward; 5) midkeel of
   upper side of hind femur with two leaf-shaped protuberance near the
   basal part; 6) outside of lower side of hind femur not black; 7) hind
   tibia dark brown. The holotype is deposited in the Institute of Zoology,
   Shaanxi Normal University. A key to species of Ergatettix from China is
   presented.
C1 Lin, Liliang; Institute of Zoology, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an,
   Shaanxi 710062, China, China.
EM zhengzhemin@163.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7482
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Ergatettix [Checklists / Checklist of species / ] [China /  / Key to
   species]. 
   Ergatettix longlingensis [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Ergatettix - Kirby 1914 (Saltatoria): [Key to species, China, P. 150].

PT J
AN ZOOR15207042903
DT Article
TI Two new species in the genus Teredorus Hancock (Orthoptera: Tetrigidae)
   from Yunnan Province.
AU Zheng, Zhemin (zhengzhemin@163.com) 
   Ou, Xiaohong
   Lin, Liliang
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 34
IS 2
PS 153-161
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new species in the genus Teredorus Hancock from Yunnan Province are
   described: T. brachinotoides sp. nov. and T. choui sp. nov.. T.
   brachinotoides sp. nov. is allied to T. brachinota Zheng & Xu, 2010, but
   differs in: 1) length of body 2.42[long dash]2.7 times its width; 2)
   frontal ridge concave before lateral ocelli in profile; 3) total length
   of pronotum about 9.35 times length of the part of hind process
   surpassing hind femur; 4) inner side of hind femur yellowish brown,
   basal part black; 5) lower inside of hind femur yellowish brown, with
   two black spots, lower outside black; 6) sternum of abdomen yellowish
   brown. T. choui sp. nov. is allied to T. albimarginus Zheng & Zhou,1996,
   but differs in: 1) length of hind process surpasses apex of hind femur
   3.50[long dash]4.00 mm ([male]) or 2.80[long dash]3.00 mm ([female]); 2)
   length of tegmina 2.5 times its width; 3) width of mid femur equal to
   tegmina; 4) midkeel of pronotum chequered with black and white; 5)
   profile of pronotum with same colour as its back; 6) lower side of hind
   femur grey brown; 7) inner side of hind femur black. A key to known
   species of the genus Teredorus Hancock is given. The type specimens are
   deposited in the Institute of Zoology, Shaanxi Normal University.
C1 Zheng, Zhemin; Institute of Zoology, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an,
   Shaanxi 710062, Chile, Chile.
EM zhengzhemin@163.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7482
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Teredorus brachinotoides; Teredorus choui [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Teredorus - Hancock 1906 (Saltatoria): [Key to species, P. 154]. 
   Teredorus brachinotoides (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 157]. 
   Teredorus choui (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 158].

TI Notes on the quercus group in the leafhopper genus Typhlocyba Germar

PS 201-206

U2 0
AB The quercus group in the genus Typhlocyba from China is reviewed. Three
   new species are described and illustrated: T. choui sp. nov., T.
   daliensis sp. nov. and T. trimaculata sp. nov. One species, T. quercus
   (Fabricius, 1777), is newly recorded from China. A key to males of the
   quercus group in China is provided.

AN ZOOR15207042912
DT Article
TI A new species in the genus Fiorinia Targioni-Tozzetti (Hemiptera:
   Coccoidea: Diaspididae) from China.
AU Zhang, Bin
   Zeng, Tao
   Feng, Jinian (jinianf@nwsuaf.edu.cn) 
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 34
IS 2
PS 222-226
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB One new species, Fiorinia nanningensis Zhang & Feng sp. nov. from China,
   is described and illustrated. The new species is similar to F. linderae
   Takagi, 1969, with both having gland spines absent on the pygidium, and
   second lobes reduced, at most represent by a slight prominence, or
   absent; but differing from the latter in: 1) median lobes of new species
   small and narrow, without notches, ends often truncated (median lobes
   large and serrate, pointed apically in F. linderae); 2) gland spines or
   gland tubercles absent on body (with 1[long dash]3 gland tubercles on
   metathorax and 3 or 4 on abdominal segment I, and 1[long dash]2 gland
   spines on abdominal segment II in F. linderae); 3) interantennal process
   absent between antennal bases (small and conical in F. linderae). The
   type specimens are deposited in the Entomological Museum of Northwest A
   & F University, Yangling, Shaanxi, China (NWAFU).
C1 Feng, Jinian; Key Laboratory of Plant Protection and Pest Management of
   Ministry of Education, Entomological Museum, Northwest A & F University,
   Yangling, Shaanxi 712100, China, China.
EM jinianf@nwsuaf.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7482
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Fiorinia nanningensis [Guangxi Zhuang /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha,
   Coccoidea
OR Fiorinia nanningensis - Zhang & Feng 2012 (Coccoidea): [Sp nov, Guangxi
   Zhuang, P. 223].

TI A review of the genus Thabena Stal (Hemiptera: Fulgoromorpha: Issidae)
   from China with description of one new species.
AU Zhang, Zhengguang (chenxs3218@163.com) 
   Chen, Xiangsheng
SO Entomotaxonomia

IS 2
PS 227-232
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The planthopper genus Thabena Stal, 1861 (Hemiptera: Fulgoromorpha:
   Issidae: Issini) is reviewed to include four species from China: T.
   hainanensis (Ran & Liang, 2006) (China: Hainan), T. lanpingensis sp.
   nov. (China: Yunnan), T. litaoensis (Yang, 1994) (China: Taiwan, Hainan)
   and T. yunnanensis (Ran & Liang, 2006) (China: Yunnan). Two species, T.
   lanpingensis and T. litaoensis, are described or redescribed and
   illustrated. A key to all species of Thabena in China is given.

AB Three species in the genus Promalactis Meyrick are reported from China.
   Promalactis saligna sp. nov. is described as new; P. tamdaoella Lvovsky,
   1988 and P. vittapenna Kim & Park, 2010 are newly recorded for China,
   with redescription of the former species. Promalactis griselocula Kim &
   Park, 2010, syn. nov., is synonymized with P. tamdaoella. Images of
   adults and illustrations of genitalia are provided.

DT Article
TI Revision of the subgenus Orthostegana (Diptera: Drosophilidae: Stegana)
   from Eastern Asia.
AU Zhang, Yuan
   Xu, Miaofeng
   Li, Tong
   Chen, Hongwei (hongweic@scau.edu.cn) 
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 34
IS 2
PS 361-374
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Eastern Asian species of the subgenus Orthostegana in the genus
   Stegana are reviewed based on the results of Li et al.'s phylogenetic
   analysis. The subgenus Anastega is fused with the subgenus Orthostegana
   as syn. nov.. Four new species are described from Yunnan, China: Stegana
   (Orthostegana) flavicauda Zhang & Chen sp. nov., S. (O.) hirsutinna
   Zhang & Chen sp. nov., S. (O.) hylecoeta Zhang & Chen, sp. nov. and S.
   (O.) multicardua Zhang & Chen sp. nov.. Two known species: S. (O.)
   curvinervis (Hendel, 1914) and S. (O.) singularis Sidorenko, 1990, comb.
   nov. are described complementally. A table showing uncorrected pairwise
   p-distance among the DNA sequences of the mitochondrial COI and ND2
   genes of six Orthostegana species is provided.
C1 Chen, Hongwei; Department of Entomology, South China Agricultural
   University, Guangzhou, Guangdong 510642, China, China.
EM hongweic@scau.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7482
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   Stegana (Orthostegana) hylecoeta; Stegana (Orthostegana) multicardua
   [Yunnan /  / New species].

   Drosophilidae

   [Referred to, Stegana (Orthostegana), p. 367, Cited by author as Comb.
   nov.].

   Syn nov, Stegana (Anastega) Sidorenko 2002, p. 364].

   [Description, P. 365].

   [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 368].

   [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 369].

   Ren, Guodong (gdren@hbu.edu.cn) 
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 34
IS 2
PS 375-377
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Lytta Fabricius 1775, Lytta choui sp. nov., is
   described from Hebei, China. Images are provided of its habitus, head,
   protibial spurs and aedeagus, and the antenna, pronotum, spiculum
   gastrale, abdominal sternite and tergite are illustrated. The type
   specimens are deposited in the Hebei University Museum, Baoding, China
   (HBUM).

   071002, China, China.

DT Article
TI A new species of Macrophya Dahlbom (Hymenoptera: Tenthredinidae) with a
   key to species of Macrophya planata group.
AU Li, Zejian
   Heng, Xuemei
   Wei, Meicai (weimc@126.com) 
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 34
IS 2
PS 423-428
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Macrophya planata species group is proposed and defined by
   mesoscutellum very flat with sharp lateral carina and the dorsal side of
   some antennomeres white. A new species of the group from Tibet, China is
   described: Macrophya acutiscutellaris Wei, Li & Heng sp. nov.. The new
   species is similar to M. pseudoplanata Saini et al., 1996, but differs
   from the latter in body length 13.5 mm in female; apical third of hind
   tibia entirely black; antenna 2.5 times as long as head breadth;
   postocellar area 1.6 times as broad as long; harpe weakly narrowed
   toward apex. A key to all known species of Macrophya planata group is
   provided. Type specimens of this new species are deposited in the Insect
   Collection of Central South University of Forestry and Technology,
   Changsha, Hunan, China.
C1 Wei, Meicai; Lab of Insect Systematics and Evolutionary Biology, Central
   South University of Forestry and Technology, Changsha, Hunan 410004,
   China, China.
EM weimc@126.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7482
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Symphyta, Tenthredinoidea,
   Tenthredinidae

   nov, Xizang, P. 425]. 
   Macrophya planata group (Tenthredinidae): [Key to species, P. 424].

DT Article
TI A new species of Emphytopsis Wei & Nie (Hymenoptera: Tenthredinidae)
   with a key to world species of the genus.
AU Wei, Meicai (weimc@126.com) 
   Zhou, Peiping
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 34
IS 2
PS 429-434
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Emphytopsis Wei & Nie from Guangxi, China is described:
   E. maculoclypea Wei sp. nov. The new species resembles E. punctata Wei &
   Nie, 1998 and E. unimaculata Wei, 2011 but differs from them in the
   anterior of clypeus and posterior of hind orbit black; the upper corner
   of mesepisternum and the ventral side of middle and hind coxae with
   black spot; the postocellar area flat, not above temple; the lateral
   furrows very fine and weak; and the area below pore line in female
   lancet about 1.8 x as high as broad. A key to the known species of the
   genus is provided.
C1 Wei, Meicai; Lab of Insect Systematics and Evolutionary Biology, Central
   South University of Forestry and Technology, Changsha, Hunan 410004,
   China, China.
EM weimc@126.com

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

DT Article
TI First record of the genus Sacculogalumna Engelbrecht (Oribatida:
   Galumnidae) in China, with description of a new species.
AU Liang, Wenqin
   Yang, Maofa (yangmaofa@sohu.com) 
   Huang, Rong
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 34
IS 2
PS 489-493
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Sacculogalumna Engelbrecht, 1973 is reported for the first
   time from China, a new species of this genus, S. suiyangensis sp. nov.,
   from Kuankuoshui National Nature Reserve in Suiyang County of Guizhou
   Province, is described. This new species is characterized by the short
   interlamellar setae or absent; slightly fusiform sensillus; distinct
   notogastral setae; small and rounded area porosa postanalis (Ap). A
   table for distinguishing the known species and new one in the genus is
   provided.
C1 Yang, Maofa; Guizhou Key Laboratory for Plant Pest Management of
   Mountainous Region, Guizhou University, Guiyang, Guizhou 550025, China,
   China.
EM yangmaofa@sohu.com

DT Article
TI Aploceble (Chalcoaploceble) viridiaeneus Tshernyshev - new subgenus and
   species of dasytid beetles (Coleopterta, Dasytidae) in Baltic Amber.
AU Tshernyshev, S.E. (sch-sch@mail.ru) 
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 11
IS 3
PS 213-218
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB New subgenus and species of dasytid beetles, Aploceble (Chalcoaploceble)
   viridiaeneus Tshernyshev, subgen. et sp.n., are described from Eocene
   Baltic amber, Kaliningrad environs, Russia. The subgenus Aploceble
   (Chalcoaploceble) subgen.n. with the type species A. (Ch.) viridiaeneus
   Tshernyshev, sp.n. differs in characters as follows: pronotum slightly
   wider than elytral base, densely and coarsely punctate and covered with
   long erect hairs; dark coloration of surface with green- or blue-bronze
   metallic lustre (Plate I: 1,2); antenna serrate from the 4th segment
   (Fig. 2); eyes large, round, protruding, the eye diameter is equal to
   the length of basal four segments of antenna (Fig. 1, Plate II: 2);
   tarsomeres elongate, claws with lamellate appendages weakly noticeable
   under amber mass. The new species can be distinguished from the
   congeners of the nominative subgenus, A. berendti Majer, 1998 and A.
   fuscipes Majer, 1998, by completely hairless eyes, and from A. kunowi
   Majer, 1998, by light colouration of legs, which are also with dark
   stripes and with metallic lustre on femora in contrast to A. fuscipes
   Majer, 1998 which legs completely yellow. Figures and photos of
   inclusion are provided. The list of fossil Dasytidae is given.
C1 Tshernyshev, S.E.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Systemat & Ecol Anim, Frunze
   Str 11, Novosibirsk, 630091, Russia, Russia.
EM sch-sch@mail.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1684-4866
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Aploceble (Chalcoaploceble) [Eocene /  / New subgenus]. 
   Aploceble (Chalcoaploceble) viridiaeneus [Russia /  / new species;
   Described from amber] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Dasytidae [Checklists /  / Species in amber] [Europe / Baltic region / ]
   [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Cleroidea,
   Melyridae
OR Aploceble (Chalcoaploceble) (Melyridae): [Subgen nov, Type species
   Aploceble (Chalcoaploceble) viridiaeneus, p. 215, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Aploceble (Chalcoaploceble) viridiaeneus (Melyridae): [Sp nov, Russia,
   Eocene, P. 215, Described from amber; Fossil]. 
   Aploceble berendti - Majer 1998 (Melyridae): [Diagnostic characters, P.
   217; Fossil]. 
   Aploceble fuscipes - Majer 1998 (Melyridae): [Diagnostic characters, P.

DT Article
TI Subgeneric classification of the genus Sphaerophoria Lep. et Serv.
   (Diptera, Syrphidae).
AU Barkalov, A.V. (bark@eco.nsc.ru) 
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 11
IS 3
PS 285-290
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Subgeneric divisions of the genus Sphaerophoria Lep. et Serv. is
   studied. Three subgenera are proposed: Knutsonia subgen.n., with type
   species Sphaerophoria novaeangliae Johnson, 1916; Proshpaerophoria
   subgen.n., with type species Sphaerophoria loewi Zetterstedt, 1843 and
   Sphaerophoria s. str., with type species S. scripta (Linnaeus, 1758).
   Four species groups were established within the type subgenus - the
   scripta group, the chongjini group, the rueppellii group and the
   abbreviata group.
C1 Barkalov, A.V.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Systemat & Ecol Anim, Frunze Str
   11, Novosibirsk, 630091, Russia, Russia.
EM bark@eco.nsc.ru

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key

ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Syrphidae
OR Sphaerophoria - Le Peletier & Serville in Latreille et al 1828
   (Syrphidae): [Redescription, Male genitalia, p. 285; Key to subgenera,
   P. 289; Key to species groups, P. 289].

   al 1828 (Syrphidae): [Diagnosis, P. 288]. 
   Sphaerophoria angulata - Claussen & Weipert 2003 (Syrphidae): [Referred
   to, New subgenus Sphaerophoria (Knutsonia), p. 288]. 
   Sphaerophoria assamensis - Joseph 1970 (Syrphidae): [Referred to, New
   subgenus Sphaerophoria (Knutsonia), p. 288]. 
   Sphaerophoria loewi - Zetterstedt 1843 (Syrphidae): [Designated type
   species for new subgenus, Sphaerophoria (Prosphaerophoria), p. 288].

   species for new subgenus, Sphaerophoria (Knutsonia), p. 288].

DT Article
TI Two new species of Arbacioid echinoids (genus Goniopygus) from the
   Aptian sediments of Baghin area (Kerman, Iran).
AU Vaziri, M.R. (Vazirimohammadreza@yahoo.com) 
   Arab, A.L.
SO Iranian Journal of Science and Technology Transaction A-Science
VL 36
IS A3
PS 231-237
PD Sum 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Two new species of an Arbacioid echinoid, genus Goniopygus, are reported
   for the first time from Aptian sediments of Baghin area, Kerman, Iran.
   The main features of the species lie in apical disc and peristome
   diameter. In Goniopygus triangularis sp. nov., the periperoct is
   triangular in shape with three small, sunken tubercles, located
   alternatively adjacent to the periperoct, while Goniopygus annularis sp.
   nov. is characterized by having a circular periperoct without any sunken
   tubercle. Also, Goniopygus triangularis has a wider peristome than
   Goniopygus annularis. In both species sexual dimorphism is not
   conspicuous. They lived in restricted to low - moderate energy
   environments.
C1 Vaziri, M.R.; Shahid Bahonar Univ, Fac Sci, Kerman, Iran, Iran.
EM Vazirimohammadreza@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1028-6276
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Goniopygus annularis; Goniopygus triangularis [Iran /  / new species] [
   / Kerman, Baghin area / new record] [Cretaceous /  / ] [ / Aptian
   sediments / ].

DT Article
TI Description of Hemicaloosia graminis n. sp (Nematoda: Caloosiidae)
   Associated with Turfgrasses in North and South Carolina, USA.
AU Zeng, Yongsan (weimin.ye@ncagr.gov) 
   Ye, Weimin
   Tredway, Lane
   Martin, Samuel
   Martin, Matt
SO Journal of Nematology
VL 44
IS 2
PS 134-141
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new nematode species was discovered during a diversity survey of
   plant-parasitic nematodes on turfgrass conducted in North and South
   Carolina in 2010 and 2011. It is described herein as Hemicaloosia
   graminis n. sp. and is characterized by two annuli in the lip region,
   one lateral line, body 610.0-805.0 [mu]m long, stylet 65.0-74.6 [mu]m
   long, vulva at 84.1% -85.8% of the body, 254-283 annuli, vulva at the
   38-53 rd annulus from tail terminus, 12-14 annuli between vulva and
   anus, tail elongate-pointed, 67.5-84.8 [mu]m long in females and spicule
   straight, 31.0 [mu]m long, caudal alae well developed, two lateral lines
   in males. The newly described species is morphologically closest to H.
   paradoxa, but has a longer stylet (65.0-74.6 vs 61.0-65.0 [mu]m) and a
   higher V-value (84.1-85.8 vs 78.1-84.0%), less RV (38-53 vs 50-56),
   higher RVan (12-14 vs 10) in females, and a shorter tail (30.1 vs 36.7
   [mu]m) and more anteriorly located excretory pore (105.9 vs 140.0 [mu]m)
   in the male. It was easily differentiated from other species based on
   near-full-length small subunit rRNA gene (SSU) and ITS1 sequences.
   Phylogenetic analysis from SSU supports placement in a monophyletic
   clade with the genus Caloosia. An identification key and a table of
   distinguishing characteristics are presented for all seven species of
   Hemicaloosia.
C1 Zeng, Yongsan; NC State Univ, Dept Plant Pathol, Raleigh, NC, 27695,
   USA, USA.
EM weimin.ye@ncagr.gov
SC Zoology
SN 0022-300X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Hemicaloosia graminis [North Carolina /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Hemicaloosia - Ray & Das 1978 (Nematoda): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 139; Key to species, Female, p. 138]. 
   Hemicaloosia graminis (Nematoda): [Sp nov, North Carolina, P. 135]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912066523
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Occurrence Ecology of Ricania sp. (Hemiptera: Ricaniidae) and Selection
   of Environmental Friendly Agricultural Materials for Control.
AU Cho, Duck-Soo (cds1218@korea.kr) 
   Kim, Do-Il
   Ko, Sug-Ju
   Kang, Beom-Ryong
   Lee, Kwan-Seok
   Park, Jong-Dae
   Choi, Kyeong-ju
SO Korean Journal of Applied Entomology
VL 51
IS 2
PS 141-148
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA Korean
U1 0
U2 2
AB An outbreak of Ricania sp. occurred in the Kurye, Jeonnam area in 2011.
   This outbreak damaged many kinds of fruit trees such as Cornus,
   Persimmon and Chestnut. This experiment was conducted to survey the
   occurrence ecology of Ricania sp. such as host plants, oviposition
   characters, morphological characters and life cycle, as well as to
   select environmental friendly control agents. Ricaina sp. host plants
   included 51 species such as 32 xylophytes, and 19 herbaceous plants.
   Ricaina sp. preferred Cornus officinalis, Diospyros kaki, Castanea
   crenata, Eucommia ulmoides, Styrax japonicus for oviposition. Adults
   laid eggs on new inner twigs with 28.8 eggs per egg-mass. Egg size was
   1.24 mm(length), 0.55 mm(width) in an oval shape. Nymphs molted four
   times. Every nymph stage had a shape of yellow or white beeswax around
   the anus. Overwintered eggs of Ricania sp. hatched from the mid May to
   early June. Nymphal periods were from mid May to mid August and adults
   appeared from mid July but spawning began in mid August. Ricania sp.
   damaged new twigs by oviposition and retarded growth by sucking
   nutrients and producing a sooty mold. Sophora and natural plant extracts
   were effective environmentally friendly agricultural materials used to
   control the nymph and adult Ricania sp. Mortality was  r80%.
C1 Cho, Duck-Soo; Jeonnam Agricultural Research and Extension Services,
   500-715, Naju, South Korea, South Korea.
EM cds1218@korea.kr
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Developmental
   Biology; Parasitology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1225-0171
BD General morphology; Reproduction; Reproductive behaviour; Life cycle and
   development; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Ecology; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Ricania [General morphology / Morphological characters / ] [Egg laying /
   Oviposition / ] [Life cycle /  / ] [Plant hosts /  / ] [Ecology /  / ]
   [South Korea / Jeonnam, Kurye / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Fulgoroidea, Ricaniidae
OR Ricania (Ricaniidae): [Parasite].

DT Article
TI High genetic diversity within Epimeria georgiana (Amphipoda) from the
   southern Scotia Arc.
AU Loerz, Anne-Nina (a.loerz@niwa.co.nz) 
   Smith, Peter
   Linse, Katrin
   Steinke, Dirk
SO Marine Biodiversity
VL 42
IS 2
PS 137-159
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB DNA barcoding revealed four well-supported clades among amphipod
   specimens that keyed out to Epimeria georgiana Schellenberg, 1931, three
   clades with specimens from the southern Scotia Arc and one clade with
   specimens from the Weddell Sea. Detailed morphological investigations of
   sequenced specimens were conducted, through light and scanning electron
   microscopy. High magnification (500-2,000 fold) revealed features such
   as comb-scales on the first antenna and trich bearing pits on the fourth
   coxal plate to be similar for all specimens in the four clades.
   Consistent microstructure character differences in the Weddell Sea
   specimens combined with high genetic distances (COI divergence > 20%)
   allowed the description of Epimeria angelikae, a species new to science.
   Specimens of E. georgiana in the other three COI clades from the Scotia
   Arc were morphologically indistinguishable. Representative specimens of
   clade A are also illustrated in detail. Our results on the high genetic
   divergences in epimeriid amphipods support the theory of the southern
   Scotia Arc being a centre of Antarctic diversification.
C1 Loerz, Anne-Nina; Natl Inst Water & Atmospher Res NIWA, Private Bag 14
   901, Wellington, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM a.loerz@niwa.co.nz
RI Steinke, Dirk/D-4700-2009
OI Steinke, Dirk/0000-0002-8992-575X; Linse, Katrin/0000-0003-3477-3047
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Techniques; Genetics; Evolution;
   Variation; Marine zones
DE Epimeria angelikae [Antarctic Ocean /  / New species]. 
   Epimeria georgiana species complex [Genetic techniques / DNA barcoding
   for species discrimination / systematics] [Identification techniques / 
   / ] [Molecular genetics / COI gene sequence diversity / ] [Population
   genetics / Population genetic structure / ] [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic
   analysis / ] [Biochemical variation /  / ] [Antarctic Ocean / Southern
   Scotia Arc / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Amphipoda
OR Epimeria angelikae (Amphipoda): [Sp nov, Antarctic Ocean, P. 142]. 
   Epimeria georgiana species complex (Amphipoda). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14808057124

TI ADDITION TO THE CRAB SPIDER (ARANEAE: THOMISIDAE) FAUNA OF INDIA.
AU Sen, Souvik (souvik_ind_06@yahoo.co.in) 
   Saha, Sumana
   Raychaudhuri, Dinendra

VL 7
IS 2
PS 909-919
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four species of crab spiders belonging to four genera are reported from
   the reserve forests of Dooars, North Bengal, India. Of these Massuria
   uthoracica, Misumena mickeyi, Pharta indica are described as new to
   science and Synema revolutum Tang & Li 2010 is a new record from the
   subcontinent. The genus Pharta Thorell, 1891 is reported for the first
   time from India. All four species are described/diagnosed and
   illustrated.

TI NEW SPECIES OF CORTODERA MULSANT, 1863 FROM TURKEY (COLEOPTERA:
   CERAMBYCIDAE).
AU Ozdikmen, Huseyin (ozdikmen@gazi.edu.tr)

TI FOUR NEW SPECIES OF HYDROPTILIDAE FROM TURKEY (TRICHOPTERA).
AU Sipahiler, Fusun (fusunsip@hacettepe.edu.tr)

VL 7
IS 2
PS 1051-1057
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of the genus Hydroptila, H. tifica sp. n., belonging to
   the occulta group, (northeastern Turkey) is described and figured. The
   species of the genus Stactobia found in Turkey are revised, and the
   following new species are described and illustrated: Stactobia alaplica
   sp. n., S. yenicensis sp. n. (northwestern Turkey) and S. kiziroglui sp.
   n., (western Turkey). Stactobia forsslundi Schmid, 1959 is newly
   recorded for Turkey. S. alaplica sp. n. and S. kiziroglui sp. n. belong
   to the furcata species group, and S. yenicensis sp. n. belongs to the
   martynovi species group.

   BENGAL, INDIA.

AB 31 species under 6 genera till date are found to compose lycosid fauna
   of Dooars, West Bengal. Of these Arctosa quinquedens is considered as
   new to science. Hitherto unknown male morph of Draposa amkhasensis
   (Tikader & Malhotra) comb. nov. is reported. Record of Pardosa procurva
   Yu & Song from the country delimits its distribution range. All these
   new spiders are described and illustrated. New combination for the
   species Draposa amkhasensis (Tikader & Malhotra) and D. burasantiensis
   (Tikader & Malhotra) is proposed.

TI SUBSTITUTE NAMES FOR HOMONYM SPECIES OF CYTHERELLIDAE (OSTRACODA:

AB For primary junior homonyms of ostracod species within the Cytherellidae
   the following replacement names are proposed: Cytherella elongatavalva
   nom. nov. for Cytherella elongata Donze, 1964; Cytherella gaasensis nom.
   nov. for Cytherella cuneata Deltel, 1963; Cytherella gupcoensis nom.
   nov. for Cytherella inflata Wasfi, El Sweify & Abdelmalek, 1982;

   Dall'Antonia, 2003; Cytherella kerryswansoni nom. nov. for Cytherella
   elongata Swanson, 1969; Cytherella obesina nom. nov. for Cytherella
   obesa Dall'Antonia & Bossio, 2001; Cytherella pierredonzei nom. nov. for
   Cytherella inaequata Donze, 1966; Cytherelloidea robinwhatleyi nom. nov.
   for Cytherelloidea malaccaensis Whatley & Zhao, 1988; and Cytherelloidea
   undosa nom. nov. for Cytherelloidea undulata Scheremeta, 1969. In
   addition, Platella drexlerae (Field, 1967) comb. nov.; Platella
   gaasensis (Kempf, 2012) comb. nov.; and Platella kempfi (Whatley, 1986)
   comb. nov. are proposed.

DT Article
TI LABRONEMA NEODIVERSUM SP N., A NEW DORYLAIMID NEMATODE SPECIES FROM WEST
   BENGAL, INDIA.
AU Mondal, S.
   Manna, B.
   Gantait, V.V. (v.gantait@rediffmail.com) 
SO Nematologia Mediterranea
VL 40
IS 1
PS 61-65
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Labronema neodiversum, a new nematode species belonging to the order
   Dorylaimida from West Bengal, India is described and illustrated.
   Labronema neodiversum sp. n. is characterized by having bodies 1.36-1.58
   mm (female) and 1.29-1.34 mm (male) long, curved ventrally. Lip region
   offset, somewhat angular. Odontostyle strong, longer than labial
   diameter; odontophore simple rod-like. Guide ring 'double'. Expanded
   portion of oesophagus occupying 43-45% of its length. Cardia
   tongue-shaped with thin cardiac disc. Vulva longitudinal. Short conoid
   dimorphic tail (with dorsally curved peg-like structure in female,
   rounded in male). Male possesses 25-27 contiguous ventromedian
   supplements with an adanal pair. It differs from other species of the
   genus and shows closest similarities with L. varicaudatum (Thorne, 1929)
   Thorne, 1939 and L. diversum Andrassy, 2002 by having the digitate tail
   in females. But it differs from L. varicaudatum in the following
   characters: shorter body, stylet longer than labial diameter, tip of the
   female tail dorsally bent. It differs from L. diversum in: tongue-shaped
   cardia, presence of an adanal pair of ventromedian supplements, caudal
   papillae inconspicuous, copulatory hump absent.
C1 Gantait, V.V.; Zool Survey India, Nemathelminthes Sect, M Block,
   Kolkata, W Bengal, 700053, India, India.
EM v.gantait@rediffmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0391-9749
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Labronema neodiversum [West Bengal /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Labronema neodiversum (Nematoda): [Sp nov, West Bengal, P. 61].

DT Article
TI A SURVEY OF PLANT-PARASITIC NEMATODES ASSOCIATED WITH FORAGE CROPS IN
   BINGOL, TURKEY.
AU Yildiz, S.
   Handoo, Z.A.
   Carta, L.K.
   Skantar, A.M.
   Chitwood, D.J.
SO Nematologia Mediterranea
VL 40
IS 1
PS 73-77
PD June 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB During June 2011, a survey was conducted in four districts of Bingol
   province, Turkey, to investigate the occurrence, population abundance
   and spatial distribution of plant parasitic nematodes associated with
   forage crops. A total of 24 soil samples were collected and processed
   for this study. The plant parasitic nematodes detected in the samples
   included Ditylenchus microdens, Filenchus sp., Helicotylenchus
   platyurus, H. carolinensis, H. varicaudatus, Longidorus sp., Meloidogyne
   sp., Merlinius bavaricus, M. brevidens, Merlinius sp., Paratrophurus
   sp., Paratylenchus tenuicaudatus, Paratylenchus sp., Pratylenchoides
   erzurumensis, Pratylenchus crenatus, P. thornei, Sauertylenchus maximus,
   Trophurus sp., Tylenchorhynchus brassicae, Tylenchus exiguus, Xiphinema
   pachtaicum and X. index. Of these, Helicotylenchus platyurus, H.
   carolinensis and Paratylenchus tenuicaudatus represent new country
   records for Turkey. In addition, all the species identified are reported
   for the first time in Bingol province, Turkey. However, the host status
   of the forage crops to these nematodes needs to be investigated.
C1 Yildiz, S.; Bingol Univ, Fac Agr, Bingol, TR-12000, Turkey, Turkey.

   tenuicaudatus [Turkey /  / New record].

   Population abundance / ] [Distribution within habitat / Spatial
   distribution / ] [Turkey / Bingol / ].

PM 22200958
DT Article
TI Morphology and histopathology of Calyptospora sp (Apicomplexa:
   Calyptosporidae) in speckled peacock bass, Cichla temensis Humboldt,
   1821 (Perciformes: Cichlidae), from the Marajo-Acu River, Maraj Island,
   Brazil.
AU Santiago, Herika (herika_santiago@hotmail.com) 
   Correa, Jose Luis
   Tortelly, Rogerio
   Menezes, Rodrigo Caldas
   Matos, Patricia
   Matos, Edilson
SO Parasitology Research
VL 110
IS 6
PS 2569-2572
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Several species of Coccidia are protozoan parasites that cause infection
   in a wide variety of animal groups. Calyptospora is an important genus
   of protozoan, which infests both freshwater and marine fish. The
   hepatopancreases of 150 speckled peacock bass captured on Maraj Island,
   Brazil were studied macro- and microscopically. Oocysts were found in 84
   (56%) of the specimens in both the examination of the fresh material by
   compression and the analysis of histological sections stained with
   hematoxylin-eosin. Small, circular, homogeneous forms in negative
   contrast had a mean diameter of 21.2 [mu]m, frequently with pyriform
   sporocysts, with a mean length of 9.2 [mu]m and width of 3.1 [mu]m, and
   a thin-walled capsule, were observed in both the hepatic and the
   pancreatic parenchyma, but were completely devoid of any inflammatory
   reaction. Calyptospora infections are documented for the first time in
   the Maraj-A[double dagger]u River.
C1 Santiago, Herika; Univ Fed Rural Amazonia, Lab Pesquisa Carlos Azevedo,
   Ave Presidente Tancredo Neves,2501,Montese 66, Belem, Para, BR-077530,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM herika_santiago@hotmail.com
RI Menezes, Rodrigo/O-8722-2019; Menezes, Rodrigo/I-5149-2012
OI Menezes, Rodrigo/0000-0003-1853-3449; 
SC Cell Biology; Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0932-0113
BD Cytology; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Calyptospora [General cell ultrastructure / Morphology / new record;
   pathology] [Piscean hosts / Cichla temensis / ] [Brazil / Para, Marajo
   Island, Marajo-Acu River / ]. 
   Cichla temensis [Protozoan parasites / Calyptospora / New record;
   pathology; morphology] [Brazil / Para, Marajo Island, Marajo-Acu River /
   ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Protozoans; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Cichlidae, Protozoa, Apicomplexa, Sporozoea, Coccidia
OR Cichla temensis (Cichlidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Calyptospora (Coccidia): [Parasite; New record].

DT Article
TI Filling biodiversity gaps: benthic hydroids from the Bellingshausen Sea
   (Antarctica).
AU Pena Cantero, Alvaro Luis (Alvaro.l.pena@uv.es) 
SO Polar Biology
VL 35
IS 6
PS 851-865
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The Bellingshausen Sea constitutes the third largest sea in the Southern
   Ocean, though it is widely recognized as one of the less-studied
   Antarctic areas. To reduce this lack of knowledge, a survey to study the
   biodiversity of its marine benthic communities was carried out during
   the Bentart 2003 and Bentart 2006 Spanish Antarctic expeditions. The
   study of the hydroid collection has provided 27 species, belonging to
   ten families and 15 genera. Twenty-one out of the 27 species constitute
   new records for the Bellingshausen Sea, raising the total number of
   known species to 37, as also do nine out of the 15 genera. Candelabrum
   penola, Lafoea annulata, and Staurotheca juncea are recorded for the
   second time. Most species belong to Leptothecata. Sertulariidae with 13
   species (48%) is by far the most speciose family, and Symplectoscyphus
   with seven species (26%), including S. bellingshauseni sp. nov. and S.
   hesperides sp. nov., the most diverse genus. Considering the whole
   benthic hydroid fauna of the Bellingshausen Sea, 18 species (69%) are
   endemic to Antarctic waters, either with a circum-Antarctic (12 species,
   46%) or West Antarctic (6 species, 23%) distribution, 23 (88%) are
   restricted to Antarctic or Antarctic/sub-Antarctic waters, and only
   three species have a wider distribution. Bellingshausen Sea hydroid
   fauna is composed of a relatively high diversity of typical
   representatives of the Antarctic benthic hydroid fauna, though with a
   surprisingly low representation of some of the most diverse and
   widespread Antarctic genera (Oswaldella and Schizotricha), what could be
   related to the fact that its shelf-inhabiting hydroid fauna remains
   practically unknown.
C1 Pena Cantero, Alvaro Luis; Univ Valencia, Inst Cavanilles Biodiversidad
   & Biol Evolut ICBiB, Apdo Correos 22085, Valencia, 46071, Spain, Spain.
EM Alvaro.l.pena@uv.es
RI Pena Cantero, Alvaro Luis/F-7888-2016
OI Pena Cantero, Alvaro/0000-0003-3056-6673
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0722-4060
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Zoogeography; Marine zones
DE Hydroida [Ecology / Biodiversity / new record; systematics]
   [Zoogeography /  / ] [Antarctic Ocean / Bellingshausen Sea / faunal
   list]. 
   Symplectoscyphus bellingshauseni; Symplectoscyphus hesperides [Antarctic
   Ocean /  / New species]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Hydrozoa, Hydroida
OR Hydroida (Hydrozoa): [New record]. 
   Symplectoscyphus bellingshauseni (Hydroida): [Sp nov, Antarctic Ocean,
   P. 859]. 
   Symplectoscyphus hesperides (Hydroida): [Sp nov, Antarctic Ocean, P.
   861]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14808053525
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14911056285
PM 23894930
DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Alterosa (Trichoptera: Philopotaminae) from
   Southeastern Brazil.
AU Jardim, Gabriela Abrantes (gabiajardim@gmail.com) 
   Dumas, Leandro Lourenco
SO Revista de Biologia Tropical
VL 60
IS 2
PS 577-580
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Philopotamidae is a large caddisfly family with 20 extant genera
   comprising about 1 000 described species worldwide. Alterosa contains 22
   described species distributed in South and Southeastern Brazil. Adults
   of the genus are very similar in general structure, but are remarkable
   for their wide variation in male genitalic morphology. The specimens
   were collected with Pennsylvania light traps and preserved in 80%
   ethanol. Alterosa nessimiani sp. nov. is described, and figured from
   male specimens collected in streams of Rio de Janeiro state,
   Southeastern Brazil. The new species is closely related to A. jordaensis
   Blahnik 2005, from which it can be distinguished by the presence of two
   spines on the intermediate appendages and by the shape of tergum X.
C1 Jardim, Gabriela Abrantes; Univ Fed Rio de Janeiro, Dept Zool, Caixa

PM 23894935
DT Article
TI Ichthyc biodiversity of seagrass meadows from the Northwest coast of
   Cariaco Gulf, Venezuela.
FT Biodiversidad ictica de praderas de pasto marino de la costa noroeste
   del Golfo de Cariaco, Venezuela.
AU Ariza A., Luis Alejandro (luisalejandroariza@gmail.com) 
   Nunez P., Jose Gregorio
   Ruiz, Lilia
   Mendez de E., Elizabeth
SO Revista de Biologia Tropical
VL 60
IS 2
PS 635-648
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 7
AB Seagrasses are highly productive coastal ecosystems with a high
   diversity and abundance of fishes, very important to support artisanal
   fisheries. We analyzed the fish community structure of Thalassia
   testudinum in the communities of Manzanillo (M) and La Brea (LB),
   Northwest coast of Cariaco Gulf, Venezuela. Samples were taken monthly
   (Nov. 2006-Oct. 2007) from each place, using a beach net. A total of 34
   810 fishes were captured, grouped into 13 orders, 36 families and 83
   species. In both areas (M and LB), the number of species was similar,
   but a variation in their abundance was found: a total of 55 species and
   13 210 organisms for M, and 58 species and 21 600 organisms for LB. The
   most abundant species and those with the highest biomasses in both areas
   were: Nicholsina usta, Haemulon boschmae, H. steindachneri, Harengula
   jaguana, Halichoeres bivittatus and Hemiramphus brasiliensis. The
   occasional visitors were the most frequent community components with a
   59%, the cyclical and permanent residents were represented by the 22%
   and 19%, respectively. The H'n average for M was of 1.71[plus or
   minus]0.64bits/ind., while for LB was of 1.95[plus or
   minus]0.51bits/ind. The diversity values were directly related to the
   evenness and inversely related to the dominance. The low values of
   similarity indexes among localities allow us to assert that these fish
   communities are dissimilar, because of the structure of each Thalassia
   meadow and their connectivity with other systems.
C1 Ariza A., Luis Alejandro; Univ Oriente, Inst Oceanog Venezuela, Cumana,
   Venezuela, Venezuela.
EM luisalejandroariza@gmail.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0034-7744
BD Ecology; Habitat; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Pisces [Community structure /  / ] [Marine habitat / Seagrass meadows /
   ] [Caribbean Sea / Venezuela, Cariaco Gulf / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata
OR Pisces (Vertebrata).

DT Article
TI The Pliocene squamate reptiles of the Atlantic coast between Mar del
   Plata and Miramar, Buenos Aires province, Argentina.
FT Los reptiles escamosos del Plioceno de la costa atlantica entre Mar del
   Plata y Miramar, provincia de Buenos Aires, Argentina.
AU Brizuela, Santiago (brizuela@mdp.edu.ar) 
   Albino, Adriana M.
SO Revista del Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales
VL 14
IS 1
PS 47-56
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Teiid and amphisbaenian reptiles from Pliocene beds along the coast of
   the Buenos Aires province, between Mar del Plata and Miramar, are
   described. They include previously listed remains as well as unreported
   material belonging to old collections. They document the presence of the
   teiid genus Tupinambis in Upper Chapadmalalan and Marplatan (Vorohuan)
   units. The extinct species "T. onyxodon" Kraglievich 1947 is considered
   invalid herein; also, previous cites of T. merianae are reevaluated as
   Tupinambis sp.. Remains of the amphisbaenid Amphisbaena sp. are
   identified in Upper Chapadmalal beds; they represent so far the earliest
   record of amphisbaenians in South America.
C1 Brizuela, Santiago; Univ Nacl Mar del Plata, Dept Biol, Funes
   3250,B7602AYJ, Mar Del Plata, Buenos Aires, Argentina, Argentina.

PT J
AN ZOOR15005024164
DT Article
TI New Patagonian Cretaceous theropod sheds light about the early radiation
   of Coelurosauria.
AU Novas, Fernando E. (fernovas@yahoo.com.ar) 
   Ezcurra, Martin D.
   Agnolin, Federico L.
   Pol, Diego
   Ortiz, Raul
SO Revista del Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales
VL 14
IS 1
PS 57-81
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Here we describe a new theropod, Bicentenaria argentina nov. gen. et
   nov. sp., from the early Late Cretaceous of Patagonia. It is represented
   by more than a hundred bones belonging to different sized individuals,
   which were buried together in disarticulation after little
   transportation. The available association of skeletal elements suggests
   a gregarious behaviour for Bicentenaria, an ethological trait also
   recorded among other theropod clades. Increasing documentation of
   monospecific assemblages of different groups of theropods suggests that
   a gregarious behaviour may have constituted the ancestral condition for
   Theropoda, at least. Bicentenaria characterizes for the surangular bone
   with a high dorsal margin and a prominent lateral shelf, a
   retroarticular process that is low, wide and spoon-shaped, and quadrate
   bone with its lateral condyle larger than the medial one. Phylogenetic
   analysis found the Chinese Tugulusaurus and the Patagonian Bicentenaria
   as successive sister taxa of all other coelurosaurs, thus revealing the
   importance of the new taxon in the understanding of the early
   diversification of Coelurosauria. In particular, Bicentenaria amplifies
   the array of basal coelurosaurs that inhabited Gondwana during the
   Cretaceous, also including compsognathids, Aniksosaurus and
   Santanaraptor. Although still restricted to a handful of forms,
   available information indicates that Gondwana was a cradle for the
   evolution of different lineages of basal coelurosaurs, different from
   those documented in Upper Cretaceous beds in the northern landmasses.
   Analysis of body size distribution in averostran theropods results in
   the identification of two main episodes of drastic size reduction in the
   evolutionary history of Coelurosauria: one occurred at the initial
   radiation of the group (as represented by Bicentenaria, Zuolong,
   Tugulusaurus, compsognathids, and Aniksosaurus), and a second episode
   occurred at the early diverification of Paraves or avialans. Reduction
   in body size may have allowed adult coelurosaurians to exploit
   ecological niches not occupied before by larger basal averostrans.
C1 Novas, Fernando E.; Museo Argentino Ciencias Nat B Rivadavia, Lab Anat
   Comparada & Evoluc Vertebrados, Angel Gallardo 470 C1405DJR, Buenos
   Aires, DF, Argentina, Argentina.
EM fernovas@yahoo.com.ar
RI Pol, Diego/A-8007-2008
OI Pol, Diego/0000-0002-9690-7517
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1514-5158
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Biometrics; Evolution; Evolutionary
   adaptation; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America; Geological
   time periods; Mesozoic
DE Bicentenaria [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Bicentenaria argentina [Argentina /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Coelurosauria [Size / Body size reduction / significance of new taxa]
   [Evolutionary adaptation /  / ] [Adaptive radiation / Early radiation /
   ] [Cretaceous /  / ] [Jurassic /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Saurischia,
   Theropoda
OR Bicentenaria (Theropoda): [Gen nov, Of Coelurosauria, Type species
   Bicentenaria argentina, p. 60, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Bicentenaria argentina (Theropoda): [Sp nov, Argentina, Cretaceous, P.
   60; Fossil]. 
   Coelurosauria (Theropoda): [Fossil].

OA DOAJ Gold

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF PARADIABOLOCRINUS FROM THE UPPER ORDOVICIAN OF CENTRAL
   KENTUCKY, USA.
AU Hearn, Paul W. (bdeline@westga.edu) 
   Deline, Bradley
SO Southeastern Geology
VL 49
IS 1
PS 25-30
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of camerate crinoid, Para-diabolocrinus teres, is
   described from the Upper Ordovician (Soudleyan-Marshbrookian),
   Curdsville member of the Lexington Limestone (Central Kentucky, USA).
   This new crinoid lacks the prominent ornamentation that defines other
   species within the genus. This species yields new information regarding
   the morphology of the genus preserving the first intact crown and
   proximal stem. In addition, apparent ontogenetic patterns observed
   within P. teres strength the position of P. stellatus within this genus.

   Carrollton, GA, 30118, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI A NEW GENUS AND SPECIES OF ECHINOID (ECHINOIDEA, SPATANGOIDA) FROM THE
   OLIGOCENE (RUPELIAN) OF MISSISSIPPI.
AU Zachos, Louis G. (lgzachos@olemiss.edu) 
SO Southeastern Geology
VL 49
IS 1
PS 43-48
PD Jun 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and species of spatangoid echinoid, Tripatagus pittsi n.
   gen., n. sp., is described from the Marianna Limestone, Lower Oligocene
   (Rupelian) of Mississippi. The family is uncertain: plating of the
   plastron suggests the family Maretiidae; ethmolytic apical system,
   presence of both peripetalous and subanal fascioles, and depressed
   petals suggest the family Brissidae or Macropneustidae. It differs from
   nearly all other genera of these families in the character of 3
   gonopores in an ethmolytic apical system, lacking a gonopore in genital
   plate 2.
C1 Zachos, Louis G.; Univ Mississippi, Geol & Geol Engn, University, MS,
   38677, USA, USA.
